Rationale

The Yellow River is the second largest river in the PRC. Its
basin spans 800,000 square kilometers (km2) and is home
to 107 million people. The Yellow River Basin is frequently
affected  by  floods  resulting  in  devastating  economic  and
social losses. The Project will reduce flooding incidence in
the  most  flood-prone  part  in  the  lower  reaches  of  the
basin.  This  will  be  achieved  by  a  combination  of
(i)
nonstructural  and  structural  measures 
strengthening  the  capacity  of  the  Government  agencies
concerned  for  adopting  an  integrated  approach  to  the
management  of  the  Yellow  River  basin,  (ii)  introducing
state-of-the-art  river  embankments  and  reservoir  flood
control  systems  technology,  (iii)  reforestation  along  the
river  embankments,  and  (iv)  raising  the  village  platform
above flood levels at the most vulnerable sites.

 I. 

THE PROPOSAL

1.
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  Report  and  Recommendation  on  a  proposed
loan to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Yellow River Flood Management (Sector)
Project.  The  Report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  Strategic
Planning  Study  for  the  Preparation  of  the  Yellow  River  Law,  and  if  the  proposed  loan  is
approved  by  the  Board,  I,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  to  me  by  the  Board,  shall
approve the TA.

II. 

INTRODUCTION

2.
The Yellow River basin is PRC’s cradle of civilization because early dynasties emerged
from  its  middle  basin  along  the  Wei  River  valley  near  the  present  city  of  Xi’an.  For  centuries,
people who lived along the Yellow River had suffered from periodic floods. The last 3,500 years
saw 26 significant changes in the lower Yellow River’s course. The river settled into its present
channel in 1855. All major dynasties made tremendous efforts to control floods along the Yellow
River.  However,  constructing  flood  control  facilities  was  formidable  work  because  the  river  is
suspended  at  the  lower  reaches  due  to  the  heavy  sediment  load  from  upstream.  Because
flooding  and  drought  throughout  history,  and  the  consequent  impact  on  poverty,  in  the  Yellow
River basin have been frequent and serious, particularly in the lower reaches, the river became
known as the "sorrow of the PRC."

3.
In August 1999, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved a TA to prepare a Yellow
River  Flood  Management  Sector  Project.1  The  TA  assisted  the  Ministry  of  Water  Resources
(MWR) to prepare the feasibility study for a flood management project in the lower reaches of
the Yellow River. The consultant’s draft final report was submitted in September 2000. A Loan
Appraisal Mission2 was fielded in December 2000 to discuss the project, objective, scope, cost,
and project implementation arrangements. This report is based on the results of the TA reports,
Government  feasibility  studies,  findings  of  ADB  missions,  and  discussions  with  central,
provincial  and  local  government  officials,  and  beneficiaries.  The  linkages  between  the  goals,
objectives, outputs, and inputs are shown in the project framework in Appendix 1.

III. 

BACKGROUND

A. 

Sector Description

1. 

Floods

4.
Population  and  economic  activity  in  the  PRC  have  increasingly  moved  onto  the
floodplains of major rivers. Despite massive investments in flood control and other works, flood
damage  has  increased  with  every  major  flood  as  evidenced  during  the  floods  of  1998.  At  the
same  time,  the  combined  demands  for  water  for  municipal  supply,  irrigation,  industry,  power,
and other uses exceed the available resources, and shortages of water for municipal supply and
irrigation are emerging as major problems, especially in northern PRC.

                                                
1  TA 3259-PRC: Yellow River Flood Management Sector Project, for $930,000, approved on 22 September 1999.
2 The  Mission  comprised  T.  Miyazato,  Senior  Project  Engineer  and  Mission  Leader;  E.  Brotoisworo,  Senior
Environment  Specialist;  S.T.  Chew,  Senior  Poverty  Specialist;  E.  Gozali,  Project  Economist;  M.  Nagata,  Senior
Program  Officer;  S.  Price,  Senior  Social  Development  Specialist;  V.  You,  Counsel;  and  Wu  Guobao,  Poverty
Specialist/Staff Consultant.

 2

The PRC is afflicted with frequent floods. Its territory extends across upper, middle, and
5.
lower  latitudes,  and  owing  to  the  influence  of  the  monsoons,  the  country  typically  has  humid
summers and dry winters. The rainfall on land averages 648 millimeters (mm) a year, which is
unevenly  distributed  over  different  regions  and  seasons.  The  average  annual  rainfall  is  over
1,600  mm  in  the  southeast  coastal  region,  gradually  decreasing  to  less  than  200  mm  in  the
northwest.  Generally,  over  half  of  the  yearly  precipitation  occurs  during  the  flood  season
between July and September. The concentration of rainfall in time and space causes disastrous
floods. The typhoons that occur over the northwestern Pacific also bring calamitous floods. Over
a  period  of  38  years  (1949-1987),  281  of  1,114  typhoons  that  occurred  over  the  ocean
(including the South China Sea) struck the PRC, bringing exceptionally heavy rains and causing
serious losses in the coastal areas.

Flooding  in  the  lower  Yellow  River  basin  has  created  widespread  hardship  for  all
6.
residents  of  the  floodplains,  regardless  of  their  income  status.  Aside  from  direct  tangible
financial  losses,  floods  inflict  major  social  costs  due  to  deaths,  injuries,  displacement  of
households/communities,  loss  of  personal  belongings,  and  a  general  disruption  to  education,
livelihood,  and  family  and  social  life.  Relocating  the  flood  victims  to  congested  evacuation
camps  exposes  them  to  epidemics  and  social  tension.  Women,  who  form  a  significant  but
underestimated  percentage  of  the  rural  labor  force,  are  typically  burdened  during  flood  events
by  obligations  to  obtain  drinking  water,  fuel,  and  food;  to  help  maintain  the  health  of  family
members and livestock; and to protect household properties. Flood-affected families themselves
must contribute labor to relief and emergency works during the floods and to the cleanup and
recovery  efforts  after  the  floodwater  recedes.  In  terms  of  livelihood,  flooding  in  the  river  basin
causes subtler yet  longer term losses to farm communities, as agricultural land suffers from a
decline  in  crop  and  tree  yields  due  to  waterlogging.  In  mitigating  flood  risks,  the  Project  will
substantially  lessen  the  likelihood  of  these  social  losses  and  stresses  for  the  residents  of  the
floodplains.

Historical records show that between 206 BC and 1949 AD, more than 1,000 significant
7.
flood  disasters  occurred  in  the  PRC,  averaging  one  every  two  years.  Notable  recent  floods
include that of (i) the Huai River in 1931, inundating 4.27 million hectares (ha) of farmland and
causing  75,000  deaths;  (ii)  the  middle  and  lower  reaches  of  the  Yangtze  River  in  1931,
inundating  more  than  3.3  million  ha  of  farmland,  affecting  28.5  million  people,  and  causing
145,000 deaths; and (iii) the Yellow River in 1933, affecting more than 3.6 million ha of farmland
and causing 18,000 deaths. From 1949 to 1988, the affected area averaged about 7.9 million ha
per  year  from  large  floods  that  occurred  in  1954,  1956,  1963,  1964,  and  1985.  Although  the
number of deaths has declined, the costs of damage have increased.

8.
The most recent flood events occurred in 1996 and 1998. The 1996 flood affected some
5.12  million  houses,  caused  4,400  deaths,  impacted  31  million  ha  farmland,  resulted  in
monetary losses of Y220.8 billion ($26.7 billion), and reduced gross domestic product (GDP) by
about 4 percent. The estimates for 1998 were 7.33 million houses, 3,656 deaths, 25 million ha
farmland,  Y248.4  billion  ($30  billion),  and  3-4  percent  reduction  in  GDP.  These  are  only
estimates, but clearly the impacts have enormous implications for economic growth and human
welfare.

2. 

Yellow River Basin

The Yellow River is the second largest river system in the PRC, covering nine provinces
9.
and autonomous regions: Qinghai, Sichuan, Gansu, Ningxia, Inner Mongolia, Shaanxi, Shanxi,
Henan, and Shandong. The river rises in the northern foothills of the Bayankala Mountains on

 3

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

the  Qinghai  Plateau  at  an  elevation  of  4,600  meters  (m).  The  total  drainage  area  is  795,000
square kilometers (km2) and has a population of 107 million.  The main river is 5,464 kilometers
(km) long (Map 1).

10.

The basin is divided into three reaches, each with distinctive characteristics:

The upper reach on the Qinghai Plateau in the west of the basin at an elevation
of over 4,000 meters above sea level (masl) is the main source of runoff in the
basin; there are many hydropower schemes in this area.
The middle reach joins the Hai River basin to the east with Mount Taihang as the
eastern  boundary,  at  an  elevation  of  1,000-2,000  masl;  the  river  flows  through
narrow gorges, and the two largest dams, Sanmenxia and Xiaolangdi, are in the
downstream part of this area.
The  lower  reach  downstream  to  the  coast  has  a  general  elevation  of  less  than
100  masl,  and  is  bounded  by  the  hilly  area  of  central  Shandong  at  400-1,000
masl; the river is suspended above the hinterland level throughout.  The estuary
area lies below 10 m, and the river discharges into the Bohai Sea.

11.
Among  the  major  river  systems  in  the  PRC,  the  Yellow  River  is  the  most  complex  in
hydrology,  hydraulics,  ecology,  and  human  intervention.  The  following  are  the  principal
characteristics of the basin:

Fragile  ecological  environment.  The  middle  reach  flows  through  the  world's
largest loess plateau, with an area of 640,000 km2. Most of the area is arid and
semiarid. Drought, wind-blown sand, and soil loss are severe.3
Deficient in water and abundant in sediment. The annual average runoff for the
Yellow River is 58 billion cubic meters (m3), only one seventh that of the Mekong
River  with  a  comparable  catchment  area.  The  annual  average  sediment  load  is
1.6 billion tons (t), making the Yellow River the most sediment-laden river in the
world.
Suspended river. The lower Yellow River has formed a suspended river with the
riverbed generally 4-6 m higher than the adjacent ground. This is due to severe
soil  loss  in  the  middle  reach  and  aggradation  year  by  year  within  the  confining
flood embankments. The potential damage to settlements and agricultural land in
the event of embankment failure is high, as the surrounding terrain is a flat plain.
Radical  course  changes.  Avulsions4  have  taken  place  throughout  geological
times. In the past four millennia, the river has entered the Yellow Sea at points up
to 800 km away from the present river mouth. The last major avulsion took place
in the 1850s.

(v)  Wider  section  upstream  than  downstream,  with  a  correspondingly  higher
conveyance capacity upstream. For example, the river width is around 10 km in
Henan Province and 2-4 km in Shandong.

                                                
3 Loess  is  yellowish  brown  loamy  soil,  usually  unstratified  and  prone  to  rain  and  wind  erosion.  ADB  has  helped  to
address difficult soils under TA 1573-PRC: Red Soils Development in Hunan Province, for $789,000, approved on
3  October  1991;  TA  1615-PRC:  Monitoring and Management of Fragile Ecosystems in Shanxi-Shaanxi-Inner
Mongolia,  for  $600,000,  approved  on  27  November  1991;  TA  2042-PRC: West Henan Agricultural Development
Project, for $600,000, approved on 29 December 1993; TA 2073-PRC: Changjiang Soil and Water Conservation
and Environmental Protection,  for  $600,000,  approved  on  24  March  1994;  TA  2119-PRC:  Forest Ecosystem
Planning  and  Agro-industrial  Pollution  Control,  for  $600,000,  approved  on  30  June  1994;  TA  2156-PRC:
Improvement of Grassland Ecosystem in North China,  for  $746,000,  approved  on  16  September  1994;  and  TA
2407-PRC: Capacity Building for Soil and Water Conservation, for $590,000, approved on 28 September 1995.

4  Sudden complete change in the course of a river, usually occurring during a flood.

 4

The lower reach of the Yellow River runs through two provinces, Henan (upstream) and
12.
Shandong (coastal area) in the central part of the Northern Plain, before flowing into the Bohai
Sea.    The  total  population  of  the  two  provinces  is  about  183  million:  94  million  in  Henan,  the
most populous among PRC’s provinces and autonomous regions, and 89 million in Shandong,
which is highly industrialized. The total product of primary industry accounts for only 16 percent
of the gross provincial product in Shandong, compared with about 25 percent in Henan. Henan
is  a  major  producer  of  wheat,  corn,  and  cotton,  mostly  grown  with  irrigation.  More  than  80
percent of the population in Henan lives in the rural area.

13.
Henan is a relatively poor interior province. In 1999, its per capita annual rural income
was  Y1,948  ($235),  88  percent  of  the  national  rural  average  of  Y2,210  ($266).  Shandong  is
located  in  the  developed  coastal  zone  and  average  annual  per  capita  income  in  its  rural  area
was Y2,550 ($307) in 1999, 31 percent higher than that in Henan. Among PRC’s 31 provinces
and autonomous regions, Henan ranked 19th in rural income, and Shandong 8th.

14.
Of the 113 counties in the flood-prone areas, 43 in Henan and Shandong are especially
vulnerable to inundation since they are located along the Yellow River and its lower tributaries.
The  counties  at  highest  risk  are  densely  populated,  with  661  persons  per  km2  and  a  total
population  of  32.8  million.  The  rural  population  in  the  flood-prone  area  is  estimated  at  28.8
million (87 percent of total), of which 10.7 million form part of the labor force. Available arable
land is limited at about 0.09 ha per person. The 43 counties include the inner floodplains (i.e.,
areas inside the main river embankments) that are home to 1.7 million residents living in 2,193
villages.

The river reach downstream of the Dongping flood retention basin, about 400 km from
15.
the  estuary,  located  in  Shandong  has  a  smaller  cross  section  with  only  about  half  the
conveyance capacity of the channel upstream. This suggests that Dongping Lake has long been
a  natural  storage  area  for  floods.  The  lake  and  an  additional  storage  area  to  the  south  are
encircled with high embankments, providing an effective flood storage capacity. The basin can
be flooded from the Yellow River via inlet flood sluices; drainage is partly to the Yellow River,
and partly to the Huai River to the south, once the flood recedes. The Dongping flood retention
basin would be flooded in the event of a flood with a return period of around once in 25 years.
The storage capacity allows the river downstream to match the upstream reach.

16.
The  loess  plateau  in  the  upper  and  middle  reaches  of  the  Yellow  River  is  the  most
severely eroded area in the world.  The total eroded area is 454,000 km2: 337,000 km2 eroded
by  water  and  117,000  km2  by  wind.  The  heavily  water-eroded  area  with  an  erosion  modulus
greater than 5,000 t per km2 per year covers 146,500 km2, nearly 40 percent of the total area of
that  category  in  the  PRC.    The  36,700  km2  of  severely  water-eroded  area  with  an  erosion
modulus  greater  than  15,000  t  per  km2  per  year  accounts  for  90  percent  of  the  total  in  this
category  in  the  PRC.  The  high  sediment  load  of  the  Yellow  River  originates  mainly  from  the
highly erosive areas of the loess plateau, i.e., from Hekouzhen to Longmen and the middle and
upper reaches of the Jing, Luo, and Wei rivers.

Measures to control sediment involve major engineering works, most notably Xiaolangdi
17.
reservoir (funded by the World Bank), which is designed to trap and contain riverborne sediment
for about 20 years in the dead storage of the reservoir.5 Long-term measures include terracing,
checkdams,  reforestation,  planting  of  grasses,  and  promotion  of  horticulture  in  the  eroding

                                                
5 Dead storage is the part of a reservoir from which water cannot be released from the lowest outlet.

 5

areas.  The  Government  plans  to  rehabilitate  157,300  km²  by  2010  (one  third  of  the  loess
plateau), and to completely rehabilitate all affected areas by 2050.

18.
Building  up  farmland  by  terracing  and  utilizing  land  behind  silt  trap  dams  will  increase
agricultural  output  and  allow  the  restoration  of  forest  and  grass  on  formerly  cultivated  sloping
land.  Vegetation  cover  may  be  improved  or  restored  by  introducing  suitable  species  of  trees,
grasses, and bushes in appropriate combinations.  The development of grass and forest areas
conserves  soil  and  water,  and  promotes  the  development  of  animal  husbandry,  forestry,  and
orchards. Conservation farming to retain moisture and soil includes fallow fields, limited tillage,
cultivating along contours, and contour furrow-and-ridge planting.

19. Water consumption in the Northern Plain has been increasing at the rate of 4.7 percent
annually. The average annual flow in the Yellow River is 58 billion m3. About 38 billion m3, or 65
percent,  is  diverted  for  irrigation;  6.4  billion  m3,  or  11  percent,  is  used  by  industries  and  cities
within the watershed; and 4.1 billion m3, or 7 percent, is diverted to cities outside the watershed
(e.g.,  Zhengzhou  City).  In  1970,  the  Yellow  River  ran  dry  in  stretches  along  Shandong  for  21
days.  In  1996,  the  dry  period  was  133  days  and  in  1997,  it  was  226  days.6  Water  shortages
have contributed to the disappearance of wetland habitats__especially in the lower reaches__and
aggravated  the  decline  of  aquatic  fauna  and  the  existing  water-quality  problems.  Water
shortages may lead to future social conflict, unrest, and food insecurity. The demand for water is
currently so high that farmers face strong competition for water from local cities and industries.

B. 

Government Policies and Plans

1. 

1988 Water Law

20.
The  Government  has  placed  high  priority  on  water  resource  management  to  minimize
the  impacts  of  floods  and  droughts.  The  basic  principles  of  water  resource  management  are
stated in the current implementing guidelines for the Water Law and related laws, such as the
Law on Water and Soil Conservation, Water Pollution Control, Flood Control, and Environmental
Protection.

(i) 

(ii) 

(iv) 

(v) 

Water  resources  are  owned  by  the  State,  to  be  developed  and  utilized  at  its
discretion. Control is to be exercised through a water rights system covering the
consumptive use of both groundwater and surface water.
A  system  for  the  unified  administration  of  basinwide  water  resources  is  to  be
adopted  in  association  with  administration  at  various  levels  and  by  various
departments  throughout  the  country.  Provinces  retain  responsibility  for  systems
within their own territory.

(iii)  Water pollution control is to be an integral part of the development and utilization

of water resources.
Service entities are to charge water fees on all consumptive uses of both surface
water and groundwater.
Allocation and consumption of water must be planned and economized through
technical and organizational measures, and reuse promoted.

21.
The 1988 Water Law’s structure and level of detail show flexibility and allow adjustments
as conditions change and new management measures are devised. An extensive body of rules,

                                                
6 During  the  dry  season  in  2000,  the  Yellow  River  flow  reached  the  sea  without  interruption  due  to  strong

Government pressure on water users in the upper and middle reaches of the river to limit use.

 6

regulations,  and  specific  legislation  has  evolved  for  implementing  the  law.  Basin  plans  are  to
underpin all other plans to ensure an optimum combination of alternatives to meet national and
local goals. Basin plans are to serve as a main component of land use plans and economic and
environmental  plans, and they  are to guide the rational layout of cities and townships and the
districts’ infrastructure. Special plans may be formulated to guide subsectors such as irrigation,
flood control, drainage, and soil conservation.

22.
The 1988 Water Law provides for the principle of charging fees for the use of water in
addition to charges for services. The fees, which vary by use and source, are to be assessed on
all  consumptive  uses  and  certain  nonconsumptive  uses  such  as  hydropower  generation.
Charges  for  all  services  should  cover  costs  of  infrastructure  and  expenses  to  maintain  and
deliver  the  service.  Regional  flood  control  is  viewed  as  a  public  responsibility  of  the
Government.  However,  charges  for  flood  control  benefits  are  levied  through  land  value
assessments and direct labor along reaches of the rivers.

23.
To clarify the diverse responsibilities for water management, the Government is revising
the  1988  Water  Law,  which  does  not  adequately  address  emerging  issues.  The  revision  will
stipulate  that  water  resources  are  to  be  administered  in  a  holistic,  unified  way,  not  by  sector.
The  proposed  amended  Water  Law  has  been  discussed  by  the  National  People’s  Congress
(NPC)  and  is  expected  to  be  approved  shortly.  For  effective  and  efficient  water  management,
implementable mechanisms for water pricing and cost recovery will be stipulated.

2. 

1997 Flood Control Law

The  Flood  Control  Law,  which  NPC  passed  on  29  August  1997,  came  into  force  on  1
24.
January  1998.  This  is  the  first  law  for  preventing  and  controlling  natural  disasters  (although
there  have  been  previous  administrative  regulations  promulgated  under  the  water  and  other
laws)  and  thus  filled  a  gap  in  the  water  legislation  system.  This  law  is  important  because  it
addresses  the  specific  nature  of  causes  and  remedial  measures  to  be  taken  to  prevent  and
control floods. It requires a unified and integrated planning approach with comprehensive river
basin  plans  prepared  by  the  river  basin  commissions,  and  at  administrative  levels  of  local
government, specifically including urban areas. The law introduced the important mechanism of
designating  "planned  reserve  zones/areas,"  where  special  rules  may  apply  on  water  use  and
activities. It further specifies requirements for operating reservoirs and other hydraulic works; for
multiple  uses  in  river  course  realignments  and  lake  embankments;  and  for  preparing  a  flood
impact  assessment  for  projects  in  flood-prone  areas.    MWR  is  primarily  responsible  for
implementing this law.

3. 

River Basin Commissions

As early as November 1949, the Government stated that use of water in any river must
25.
be planned in a unified manner and managed in an integrated way so that water resources can
be  optimally  utilized.  The  principle  of  united  water  administration  relies  on  centralized
management  to  verify  water  rights  and  appraise,  decide,  and  initiate  water  conservation
undertakings with multiple objectives. During the 1950s, river basin plans were completed for all
seven major river basins. The importance of basin planning and management was confirmed by
the 1988 Water Law.

There are currently six commissions for interprovincial river basins (Songhua-Liao, Hai,
26.
Yellow,  Huai,  Yangtze,  and  Pearl)  and  one  lake  commission  (Tai)  under  the  direct
administration of MWR, but established with the consent of the State Council. The functions of

 7

the  commissions  are  delegated  to  them  by  MWR.  Many  have  been  allocated  responsibilities
that go beyond the particular river or lake basin concerned, so they essentially act as regional
offices of the ministry. The Yellow River Conservancy Commission (YRCC) is authorized to act
in some inland river basins (e.g., in Xinjiang) and the Tai Lake Commission was recently made
responsible for some rivers in Fujian Province. While the river basin commissions are primarily
responsible for the specific river or lake basins for which they are named and are widely seen to
be basin agencies, in practice they fall short of a true basin commission as they do not have the
requisite authority for implementing an integrated approach for water resource management.

4. 

River Basin Plans

27.
MWR is preparing a long-term Comprehensive River Basin Plan covering a period of 20-
30 years for each of the seven major river basins.7 MWR has also prepared flood control plans,
irrigation plans, water and ecology conservation plans, and water resources development plans
for each of the seven basins.

YRCC  prepared  an  Outline  Management  Plan  for  the  Yellow  River  Basin  covering  the
28.
period  2000-2020.  After  review  by  MWR,  YRCC  submitted  the  plan  to  the  State  Development
Planning Commission (SDPC) in 1997. The objectives of the plan are to (i) reinforce the lower
Yellow  River  embankments  to  eliminate  vulnerable  locations,  (ii)  strengthen  the  riverbank  and
train  the  bed  to  control  the  shifting  of  the  main  stream,  (iii)  slow  down  the  extension  of  the
estuary into the sea, (iv) improve the safety of the Yellow River floodplain and reduce the losses
and impacts of floods, and (v) strengthen nonstructural measures for flood management.

MWR has prepared a medium-term plan for the Yellow River called a Program for 2010.
29.
In  addition,  MWR  prepared  the  Tenth  Five-Year  Plan  (10th  FYP)  for  the  Yellow  River (2001-
2005) and submitted it to SDPC. For the lower reach of the Yellow River, the total investment
under the 10th FYP is estimated at Y27.6 billion (about $3.3 billion). The proposed Project will
cover the implementation of the most urgent construction works of both structural measures and
nonstructural measures included in the 10th FYP for the Yellow River.

30.
The major flood  of 1998 in the Yangtze and Songhua rivers and drought in the Yellow
River  basin  catalyzed  public  awareness  on  the  severity  of  the  degradation  of  the  natural
vegetation and potential environmental and economic consequences. In response to the public
concern, the Government initiated a Natural Forest Protection Project to (i) terminate logging in
natural  forests  in  designated  provinces,  (ii)  convert  cultivated  sloping  land  to  forest  and
grassland,  (iii)  regenerate  barren  land,  and  (iv)  restructure  the  forest  industry  and  re-employ
forest  workers  and  affected  farmers.  This  project  for  the  upper  and  middle  Yellow  River  was
incorporated in the Great West Development Program in 2000.

The  PRC  adopted  a  number  of  measures  to  protect  and  improve  the  ecological
31.
environment in the western region. Pilot programs were launched in 188 counties for restoring
forest  and  grassland  in  700,000  ha  of  cultivated  land  to  prevent  soil  erosion.  In  addition,
530,000  ha  of  mountainous  areas  were  closed  for  afforestation.  All  sloping  and  ecologically
important  farmland  with  serious  water  and  soil  erosion  problems  will  be  restored  as  forest  or
grassland in the next 5-10 years. The central Government also plans to bring under control the
water and soil erosion in areas totaling 20 million ha. Erosion by wind and sand storm will also
be controlled in areas totaling 26 million ha.

C. 

External Assistance to the Sector

1. 

ADB’s Operations in the Water Sector

ADB’s involvement in the water sector, especially in the water supply sector, has been
32.
significant.  ADB  has  provided  14  loans  for  water  supply,  wastewater  treatment,  and  flood
damage rehabilitation totaling $1,818 million since 1992. It has financed TAs in the environment,
water supply, and flood control sectors totaling $36.757 million: (i) 36 advisory TAs focused on
the  preparation  of  policies  and  strategies,  amounting  to  $23  million;  and  (ii)  16  project
preparatory TAs amounting to $13.75 million. A list of TAs and loans is in Appendix 2.

33.
ADB has been increasingly involved in the water resource management sector including
flood  control  since  1998.  During  implementation  of  the  TA  for  strategic  options  for  the  water
sector,8  ADB  invited  external  agencies  that  were  involved  in  the  water  sector  in  the
PRC__Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  (AusAID),  Canadian  International
Development Agency (CIDA), Deutsche Gesellschaf für Technische Zusammenarbeit (German
Agency  for  Technical  Cooperation)  [GTZ],  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency,  World
Bank__to several workshops to discuss the outcome of the study together with high-ranking PRC
officials in charge of policy and planning in the water sector (including an expert panel of senior
advisers in the sector). All participants recognized the value of the outcome of the study. The TA
identified seven major issues: (i) lack of unified water administration and management; (ii) gap
between  policy,  planning,  and  implementation;  (iii)  inadequacy  of  financial  resources;  (iv)
escalating  flood  damage;  (v)  water  scarcity  and  inefficient  water  use;  (vi)  increasing  water
pollution; and (vii) soil erosion and ecosystem degradation. Soil and water conservation projects
that contribute to poverty reduction are viewed as a potential area for future investment.

D. 

Lessons Learned

39.
International experience suggests that floods are most effectively addressed through an
optimal combination of structural and nonstructural measures. In the past, the PRC had tended
to stress structural approaches, but now it increasingly recognizes the need to move toward a
more  comprehensive  approach  by  conducting  a  broad-ranging  review  of  flood-related  policies
and practices. This trend accelerated after the devastating 1998 floods. Flood control is being
considered as integral to soil and water conservation. Other aspects will include flood-proofing
and  limiting  development  in  flood  retention  areas,  conserving  natural  lakes,  and  strengthening
vulnerable embankments.

40.
The  importance  of  sound  watershed  management  was  pointed  out  in  a  number  of
project  performance  audit  reports  (PPARs).  Many  communities  have  experienced  increasing
and  severe  flooding  after  storms  or  prolonged  rains  partly  due  to  the  effects  of  denudation  of

E. 

ADB’s Sector Strategy

43.
ADB’s  strategic  objectives  for  the  PRC  are  to  (i)  improve  economic  efficiency,  (ii)
promote  economic  growth  and  reduce  poverty  in  the  inland  provinces,  and  (iii)  enhance
environmental  protection  and  natural  resources  management.  ADB’s  strategic  actions  in  the
environment include (i) building institutional capacity; (ii) improving the policy, legal, regulatory,
and  management  systems;  (iii)  promoting  cleaner  technologies;  (iv)  supporting  the  use  of
economic  measures,  supply-side  measures,  and  other  measures  to  protect  and  ensure
sustainable use of natural resources; and (v) promoting environmentally sustainable agricultural
and natural resource management practices. The Project will address both ADB’s strategic and
environmental objectives in the water sector.

In line with ADB’s water policy,17 the Project focuses on the need for an integrated water
44.
resources management approach. The policy emphasizes that water is a socially vital economic
good that needs careful management to sustain equitable economic growth and reduce poverty.
Conserving  and  protecting  water  resources  through  a  participatory  approach  and  following
principles of integrated water resources management are at the heart of the policy.

45.
Sector capacities require strengthening in a variety of ways. The policy environment, the
sector  institutions,  and  the  development  of  human  resources  working  in  the  sector__all  need
upgrading.  The  public,  the  private  sectors,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  and
community  organizations  active  in  the  sector  need  help  with  institutional  development  and
analysis,  water  policy  formulation,  legislation,  water  resource  planning,  real-time  management
of  basin  operations,  data  management  and  interpretation,  simulation  modeling  and  other
analytical techniques, socioeconomic analysis and skills, community skills, and monitoring and
evaluation  (M&E).  ADB  will  help  determine  priorities  in  capacity  building  and  selectively  assist
its partners through a process of monitoring, training, research, and feedback. Good practices
will  be  combined  and  agencies  encouraged  to  adopt  systems  of  incentives  that  create  the
demand for improved capacity.

F. 

Policy Dialogue

1. 

Comprehensive Basin Management

46.
Effective water policy planning and implementation involve many institutions. The Project
will  focus  on  developing  effective  cross-sector  coordination  mechanisms.  During  project
processing,  the  need  to  strengthen  the  legal  framework  governing  the  Yellow  River  was
stressed.  It  was  agreed  that  ADB  would  support  the  review  and  revision  of  water  legislation,
particularly  in  the  areas  of  water  rights  and  allocation  among  competing  uses,  water  quality
standards,  groundwater  use,  demand  management,  resource  conservation,  private  sector
participation, and institutional responsibilities for water sector functions at national, regional, or
basin, local, and community levels.

47.
ADB helped to promote the holistic approach to water resources management under the
TA  for  strategic  options  for  the  water  sector (footnote  8).  One  of  the  recommendations  of  the
study  was  to  establish  a  national  water  resources  coordinating  committee  to  direct  and
supervise new initiatives in the water sector, including comprehensive basin management. The
Government  intends  to  establish  a  water  resource  management  committee,  which  was
endorsed during an NPC conference in March 2001.

48.
Recognizing the importance of coordinating activities based on hydrological boundaries
and  those  based  on  administrative  boundaries,  in  December  1997  and  October  1999,  NPC
recommended that the State Council prepare a Yellow River law for basinwide, integrated water
resources  management  of  the  Yellow  River,  to  deal  with  issues  of  scarcity  of  water  and
overcommitment of available water resources, flood hazards, soil erosion, and serious pollution.
Considering the urgency, the State Council placed very high priority for the establishment of the
Yellow River law on its legislative agenda, after the amendments of the 1988 water law.

An  associated  TA__Strategic  Planning  Study  for  the  Preparation  of  the  Yellow  River
49.
Law__will  help  the  Government  to  analyze  the  physical,  socioeconomic,  and  legal  issues  and
impediments in enacting the Yellow River law. The study will assist in resolving (i) coordination

of local laws and regulations, which are currently enforced only within the jurisdiction of riparian
provinces, townships, and villages;  (ii) conflict between water users in sectors and jurisdictions;

2. 

Cost Recovery Mechanisms

The  PRC  policy  to  levy  a  fee  for  the  privilege  of  diverting  water__surface  water  and
50.
ground water__for consumptive and other specified uses is separate and in addition to the policy
to charge for all water-related services. The decision to levy the fee and its specific use is left to
the  province  and,  where  assessed,  is  usually  collected  by  the  county  Department  of  Water
Resources  (for  rural  users)  and  county  Department  of  Construction  (for  urban  users)  to  be
shared  with  governments  at  other  levels.  In  many  instances,  several  agencies  seek  to  be
allowed to collect the fees. The Water Law states that the fee may be used only for improving
water management.

51. Water  prices  at  present  reflect  mainly  variable  costs  and  fail  to  provide  for  recovery  of
fixed  investments.  Starting  with  new  projects,  MWR  has  recommended  raising  water  prices  to
encourage efficiency. MWR anticipates the new pricing system will promote water conservation,
stimulate greater private sector participation in water supply, and reduce future water shortages.
Irrigation  water,  about  70  percent  of  total  water  use,  faces  a  threefold  price  increase,  while
urban and industrial water prices also will rise. Low prices stifle investment in water supply and
treatment facilities.

Over  the  last  decade,  the  Government  has  increased  the  budget  to  improve  and
52.
strengthen the flood protection facilities in the major river basins, almost 15 times more in 1999
than in 1990. Investment for flood protection is expected to be further increased under the 10th
FYP.  Embankments  will  be  improved  and  strengthened  for  effective  flood  protection  and
minimal  flood  damage.  At  the  same  time,  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs  will  be
increased to ensure the financial and physical sustainability of the embankments.

53.
Because of budgetary constraints faced by central and local governments, growing fiscal
concerns,18 and the large increases in flood protection investments, the Government has seen
the  need  to  recover  costs,  particularly  for  O&M,  from  beneficiaries  in  all  major  river  basins,
including  the  Yellow  River.  In  the  other  major  basins__the  Yangtze  and  Songhua__provincial
governments  have  been  levying  and  collecting  fees  for  O&M  of  the  river  infrastructure.  The
Water  Law  (1988),  to  be  amended  shortly,  is  likely  to  stipulate  a  standard  cost-recovery
mechanism  based  on  the  charges  to  be  collected  from  water  users  and/or  levied  on
beneficiaries.  Increased  tariffs  will  provide  market-based  incentives  to  conserve  and  recycle
water and put a scarce resource to the most productive use.

54.
The associated TA will assist in developing appropriate mechanisms for collecting water
charges  to  cover  O&M  costs  of  the  flood  control  facilities.  Since  the  amended  Water  Law  will
stipulate only the principle of the need to recover O&M costs from water users and beneficiaries,
developing  and  implementing  the  actual  mechanism  will  be  left  to  the  provincial  governments
and  river  basin  commissions.  The  TA  will  address  this  issue  by  analyzing  best  international
practices and will provide inputs in formulating implementation regulations under the proposed
Yellow River Law.

3. 

Strengthening  the  Legal  and  Regulatory  Framework  for  Environmental
Management

55.
Environmental  management,  including  planning  for  conservation  of  natural  resources
and protection of water resources, is a recent concern in the PRC. To help build the necessary
capacity to strengthen the legal framework, ADB (i) helped train the staff of the Environmental
Protection  Commission  of  NPC  and  is  assisting  in  drafting  and  revising  some  of  PRC's
environmental laws,19 (ii) is helping to promote a more effective legal/regulatory framework for
environmental  protection  that  is  responsive  to  PRC's  transition  to  a  market  economy  and  its
adherence to international environmental protection agreements, (iii) is helping to draft the 1996
amendments to PRC's Water Pollution Law and Environmental Protection Law and assess the
provincial water pollution law in Sichuan, and (iv) is also helping to develop a legal information
system  to  support  the  drafting  of  environmental  laws  by  the  Environment  Protection
Commission  and  other  activities.  The  Environmental  Protection  Law  will  strengthen
environmental protection in the PRC through improved administrative practices, regulations, and
provision of future legislation.

56.
A  key  area  in  ADB's  policy  agenda  in  the  PRC  is  addressing  the  problem  of  trans-
boundary  pollution.20  ADB  is  helping  to  strengthen  institutions  and  address  transjurisdictional
environmental  management  issues,  with  emphasis  on  pollution  in  the  Yellow  River.  The
experience  and  output  of  the  Yellow  River  case  study  will  be  used  to  strengthen  the
transjurisdictional  environmental  management  system  in  the  six  other  major  river  systems  as
well as minor river systems affecting two or more provinces.

4. 

Livelihood Restoration After Resettlement

acquisition and resettlement, as necessary, to ensure that affected people will reach or surpass
their  previous  living  standards  as  early  as  possible.  The  1998  Land  Administration  Law21
specifies that regulations for large or medium-size water conservation and hydroelectric projects

Regulations  for  Land  Acquisition  and  Resettlement  for  Large  and  Medium  Water  and
Hydropower  Project  Construction  to  enhance  planning,  income  restoration,  monitoring,
supervision,  and  redress  of  grievance  among  project  sponsors,  and  the  state  and  local
governments.22  The  revised  regulations  also  take  account  of  higher  compensation  standards
introduced under the 1998 Land Administration Law, and enhanced provisions under that Law
for  planning,  consultation,  and  supervision.    Pending  approval  of  the  new  MWR  Regulations,

58.
Site  surveys  and  stakeholder  consultations  confirm  that  timely  income  restoration
following  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  poses  a  significant  challenge  in  river  basin
infrastructure projects. Scope exists for intra- and inter-agency dialogue to support the revised
regulations  by  strengthening  the  application  of  appropriate  legislation  and  compensation
standards,  and  by  developing  participatory  planning  processes,  appropriate  production
techniques  and  training,  poverty  reduction  support  mechanisms,  and  accessible  credit  lines.
The  Project  will  support  specialized  research  and  its  presentation  through  an  annual  meeting,

document initial subproject livelihood restoration activities for presentation in the annual forum.
The findings of these research activities will provide relevant case study material to guide policy
application to river-based resettlement throughout the PRC.

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

59.
Frequent  flooding  causes  poverty  and  human  suffering  and  is  a  major  constraint  to
socioeconomic  development in  the Yellow River basin. The lower reaches of the Yellow River
are the worst affected. Although floods have been contained within certain limits, effective flood
management  and  soil  erosion  control  have  not  been  achieved.  Because  of  increasing
population  and  corresponding  economic  activities  in  flood-prone  areas,  the  economic  damage
caused  by  flooding  is  increasing.  There  is  a  need  to  shift  from  flood  control  to  flood
management  through  an  integrated  land  and  water  resources  management  approach  that
includes  soil  conservation  in  the  upper  catchment,  optimal  water  management  throughout  the
basin, flood control measures, and complementary flood forecasting and warning systems in the
lower reaches.

60.
The embankments and river training works at several vulnerable points along the Yellow
River  need  major  repair  and  maintenance.  The  embankments  around  flood  retention  basins
need strengthening to reduce the risk of failure. Establishing a morphological prediction system
along the lower reach including the estuary will allow sustainable flood management. To give a
higher  level  of  security  to  vulnerable  people,  old  infrastructure  (roads,  bridges,  platforms,
temporary shelters, etc.) must be upgraded and new ones constructed on the floodplain and in
retention basins.

61.
The Government’s 10th FYP for the Yellow River and MWR’s Program for 2010 for the
Yellow River give the strategic direction in implementing flood management works in the basin
(para.  29).  The  Executing  Agency,  MWR,  and  the  Implementing  Agency,  YRCC,  are  well-
established  and  experienced  in  the  flood  control  sector  and  have  the  necessary  capability  to
implement the proposed Project. Many relatively small-scale subprojects are dispersed over 800
km and will be developed in stages. ADB’s sector loan modality is appropriate for a project that
comprises a few core subprojects and about 30 subprojects to be identified and appraised in the
course  of  implementation.  The  sector  loan  approach  will  provide  necessary  flexibility  in

 15

preparing  and  implementing  subprojects  in  a  phased  manner,  consistent  with  the  local
implementation capacity.

B. 

Objective and Scope

62.
The  Project  aims  to  reduce  the  incidence  and  damage  of  flooding  in  the  lower  Yellow
River  basin  through  improved  flood  management.  The  Project  will  also  help  to  enhance  the
environment and protect the poor and near-poor by strengthening/improving protection against
floods that could push them further into poverty through the loss of crops, incomes, and assets.

The project area23 is the lower reach of the Yellow River from downstream of Xiaolangdi
63.
Dam  to  the  Bohai  Sea,  a  distance  of  some  800  km.  It  covers  3,956  km2  where  1.731  million
people  live  in  2,071  villages    (Map  2).    The  area  includes  the  inner  floodplain,  the  main
embankments and the adjacent land in the outer floodplain. This area, including parts of the Hai
and  Huai  river  basins,  is  part  of  the  117,900  km2  in  the  Northern  Plain  vulnerable  to  flooding
from the Yellow River.

64. While  preparing  the  10th  FYP  for  the  Yellow  River,  YRCC  also  prepared  prefeasibility
reports for subprojects in the project area. Considering these reports, ADB and YRCC agreed
on the priority of certain project components. As recommended in the study on strategic options
for  the  water  sector  (footnote  8),  the  importance  of  nonstructural  measures  for  flood
management  was  duly  recognized.  Source  control  and  watershed  management  measures  are
centered on holistic river basin management planning presenting an integrated approach, with
full  attention  to  environmental  issues.  The  following  are  the  four  project  components:  (i)  flood
management  measures,  (ii)  flood  control  works,  (iii)  village  flood  protection,  and  (iv)  project
management.

1.

2. 

Flood Control Works

Embankments  of  the  lower  reach  are  essential  structures  for  containing  the  Yellow
66.
River.  The river in flood is a dangerous water body 800 km long and up to 20 km wide, held
behind  embankments  up  to  14  m  above  the  surrounding  land  level.  Only  the  embankments
prevent the floodwaters from inundating vast areas of valuable land.  The body of floodwater is
powerful and turbulent, and aggressively attacks the embankments in ways that are difficult to
predict. Major investments have been made in enclosing the area with a high flood embankment
and in flooding and drainage sluices. Many structural problems within the existing embankments
have accumulated over time: (i) non-homogeneous soil, (ii) joints between construction layers,
(iii) lack of proper compaction, (iv) historical breaches and avulsions leaving weak foundations,
(v) emergency repairs carried out with materials immediately available, and (vi) wild animal dens
and burrows.

Flood  control  works  will  involve  (i)  strengthening  the  existing  embankment  including
67.
constructing  cutoff  walls24  in  the  embankment,  (ii)  river  training,  (iii)  strengthening  the  role  of
retention  reservoirs,  and  (iv)  planting  trees  along  the  embankment.  About  120  km  of
embankment will be strengthened, about 25 km of river training works will be implemented, and
six vulnerable spots of the embankment will be reconstructed. Considering the location, scale of
works,  accessibility,  and  urgency,  the  embankment  at  Kaifeng  and  Dongping  flood  retention
basin  were  selected  as  two  core  subprojects  representative  of  subprojects  under  this
component (Appendix 3).

3. 

Village Flood Protection

68.
To  meet  normal  flood  safety  standard,  elevated  earth  platforms  within  a  few  meters  of
the existing villages will be constructed using compacted riverbed material. Main and secondary
evacuation  roads  will  be  constructed  or  upgraded,  and  bridges  will  be  rehabilitated.    The
drainage system will be improved to minimize waterlogging in the area. Trees and grasses will
be planted to stabilize and protect the newly built platform slope.

69.
YRCC, in coordination with the respective local governments, will design and implement
raising of the village platform. Intensive public consultation between the local governments and
villagers who will occupy the newly constructed platform will be conducted. Public infrastructure-
related  activities,  such  as  water  supply  pipes,  installation  of  electricity  lines,  and  relocation  of
schools and clinics and village offices, will be the responsibility of both the township government
and  the  county  government  concerned,  which  will  bear  the  financial  burden  between
themselves. As a result of the Mission’s policy dialogue, the costs of relocation and resettlement
and for construction of new houses on the adjacent platform for the poor25 will be borne by the
local  government  concerned;  these  costs  will  be  above  and  beyond  the  compensation  that  is

 17

due  the  poor  based  on  the  agreed-upon  compensation  rates  for  house  relocation.26  The  local
governments have agreed to construct all public infrastructure and the houses for the extremely
poor within two years after construction of the new platform. Considering the location, scale of

Project Management

  A  PMO,  consisting  of  three  divisions,27  has  already  been  established  in  YRCC  to

design,  and  tender  documents;  provide  technical  support  to  the  construction  site  offices;  and
prepare  progress  reports.  Two  project  implementation  offices,  one  in  Shandong  Province  and
the other in Henan Province, will be established for day-to-day supervision of construction and

71.
The  social  and  environmental  functions  of  the  PMO  will  be  strengthened,  particularly
with  respect  to  the  preparation  of  IEEs  and  resettlement  plans  for  the  subprojects.  ESD  will

 D. 

Financing Plan

18

73.
The PRC has requested a loan of $150 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to
help finance the Project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period of 5 years,
an  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  a
commitment charge of 0.75 percent per annum, a front-end fee of 1.0 percent (the fee will be
capitalized in the Loan), conversion options that may be exercised in accordance with the terms
of  the  draft  Loan  Agreement,  the  Loan  Regulations,  and  ADB’s  Conversion  Guidelines,  and
such  other  terms  and  conditions  set  forth  in  the  draft  Loan  and  Project  Agreements.  The
Government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for PRC’s decision to borrow under ADB’s
LIBOR-based lending facility on the basis of these terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking
that these choices were the PRC’s own independent decision and not made in reliance on any
communication or advice of ADB. In addition, the Government of Denmark has agreed to make

E. 

Executing and Implementing Agencies

75.
  MWR  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  of  the  Project  and  YRCC  will  be  responsible  for
implementation.  The  village  flood  protection  component  will  be  implemented  by  YRCC  in

 19

MWR  is  responsible  for  developing  and  formulating  medium-  to  long-term  policies  and
76.
planning,  drafting  of  legislation;  supervising  law  enforcement,  unified  management  of  water
resources,  comprehensive  basin  planning;  organizing  water  extraction,  permit,  and  fee
collection systems; flood control and drought management; and review of feasibility studies for
large and medium-size water projects. MWR is linked vertically to water resource departments
in each of the provinces, which have comparable responsibility to MWR at the provincial level.
MWR  has  well-qualified  planning  and  engineering  staff  and  has  a  track  record  of  managing  a
variety  of  complex  water  sector  projects  (footnotes  12  and  13).  These  projects  have  been
technically well-planned and implemented.

77.
Reflecting  the  importance  of  water  resources,  the  central  Government’s  annual  budget
allocated  to  MWR  for  water  management  projects  increased  from  Y2  billion  in  1990  to  Y13
billion in 1997, and then to around Y30 billion level from 1998 to 2000. Because floods cause
severe  damage  to  people's  lives  and  the  national  economy,  almost  80  percent  of  the  total
central  Government  budget  for  the  sector  has  been  allocated  to  flood  control  projects  since
1998.

78.
YRCC was established in 1933 as one of seven interprovincial river basin commissions
under  the  direct  administration  of  MWR.  The  State  Council  in  1994  made  YRCC  solely
responsible for river management in the Yellow River basin. YRCC also assumed responsibility
for  the  Xinjiang  inland  river  basin  and  the  Inner  Mongolia  Autonomous  Region.  Reflecting  its
strong engineering capabilities, YRCC was an implementing agency in the construction of large
reservoirs in the Yellow River basin, such as Sanmenxia dam and Xiaolangdi dam.

YRCC  regulates  the  abstraction  of  water  from  the  main  stream  and  tributaries  across
79.
provinces. It controls the total volume of water diverted by the provinces along the Yellow River
in accordance with the water allocation scheme approved by the State Council. Following water
distribution  management  rules,  YRCC  coordinates  the  operations  of  Liujiaxia,  Wanjiazhai,
Sanmenxia,  and  Xiaolangdi  reservoirs  on  the  main  stream,  and  the  Guxian  and  Luhun
reservoirs, and Dongping flood retention basin on the tributaries (Map 1). YRCC issues monthly
and 10-day water distribution plans as well as water distribution for emergency allocations.

YRCC  employs  30,000  people:  9,120  are  professionals  of  whom  3,580  are  engineers
80.
and 715 are senior engineers.  Many of the engineers were involved in constructing large dams
such  as  Xiaolangdi  dam  and  Sanmenxia  dam  on  the  upper  and  middle  reaches  of  the  Yellow
River.  The  Reservoir  Resettlement  Division  has  39  people  who  have  experience  in  resettling
about 200,000 people from the Xiaolangdi reservoir site, and trained under technical assistance
from the World Bank. YRCC has an extensive network of offices in the Yellow River basin for
O&M  of  embankment  and  flood  control  facilities.  In  the  lower  reaches  alone,  there  are  2
provincial  river  affairs  bureaus,  2  project  bureaus,  13  regional  or  city  river  affairs  bureaus,  52
county  or  district  river  affairs  bureaus,  13  gate  management  stations,  and  4  flood  retarding
offices.

81.
The  local  governments,  including  the  county  and  township  project  leading  groups  and
the  working  groups,29  will  carry  out  some  resettlement  activities,  such  as  public  consultation,

M&E,  and  complaint  management.  The  capacity  of  local  governments  to  fulfill  these  activities
will be further strengthened through training and consulting inputs (paras. 90 and 96).

4. 

Land Acquisition and Resettlement

86.
A summary resettlement plan prepared for three core subprojects was circulated to the
Board  on  2  February  2001,  together  with  summary  IEEs  (SIEEs).  MWR  has  overall
responsibility for acquiring land and resettling people for the Project, working through YRCC and
the  provincial  governments  of  Henan  and  Shandong.  The  IEE  and  resettlement  plans  have
been  disclosed  to  the  public.  The  resettlement  plan  prepared  for  each  of  the  three  core
subprojects, as a model consistent with ADB's guidelines, will be used as a basis for preparing
the  resettlement  plans  for  future  subprojects.  For  future  subprojects,  any  land  acquisition  and
resettlement effects will be addressed, and full or short resettlement plans will be prepared as
appropriate  to  the  magnitude  of  impact,  following  the  resettlement  policy  framework  and  the
resettlement procedural guidelines set out under the resettlement sector lending arrangements
in Appendix 7.

87.
Resettlement  plans  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  relevant  laws  and
regulations,  including  the  Land  Administration  Law  of  1998,  and  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary
resettlement. All persons affected by land acquisition for the subprojects will be compensated in
a timely manner and resettled in accordance with the resettlement plan so that they will be at

5. 

Training Program

90.
Training  will  be  conducted  for  about  400  staff  members  of  YRCC  and  selected  local
government  officials  involved  in  implementing  resettlement,  environmental  aspects,  and
economic  evaluation  of  the  candidate  subprojects.  To  provide  targeted  training  inputs  and  in
consultation  with  the  international  consultants,  national  institutions  with  specific  expertise  in
these areas will be selected and engaged in accordance with selection criteria and procedures
acceptable to ADB.

91.
Implementing the nonstructural measures for flood management involves research and
development in the methodology and adoption of new technologies tested elsewhere. Essential
to the activities are well-trained groups of people at YRCC. International and domestic experts
will  be  required  to  set  up  the  flood  forecasting  and  warning  system  and  the  morphological
modeling  systems,  deploy  advanced  survey  equipment,  establish  ESD,  and  transfer  the
technology to YRCC staff. Technology transfer will be achieved by a combination of on-the-job
training and specialized training courses conducted overseas and in the country.

92.
Training  in  resettlement  will  be  offered  to  members  of  the  county  and  township  project
leading  groups  and  working  groups  in  designated  subproject  sites.  The  training  will  cover
applied  aspects  of  resettlement  legislation  and  compensation,  participatory  social  survey  and
site  planning  methods,  management  of  resettlement  activities  and  funds,  techniques  for
restoring livelihood, and practical M&E techniques. This training will be at standards appropriate
to  the  functional  responsibilities  and  interests  of  participants  and  based  on  a  simple  needs
assessment process. A qualified domestic consultant will conduct a needs assessment for the
training, involving the YRCC resettlement staff in a learning capacity.  Responsibility for further
developing and conducting locally appropriate training courses will then pass on to YRCC staff

6. 

Procurement

a. 

Equipment, Vehicles, and Civil Works

Goods  and  services  for  ADB-financed  contracts  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with
93.
ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Procurement.  Major  contracts  for  equipment  valued  at  more  than
$500,000 will be undertaken through ADB’s international competitive bidding (ICB) procedures.
Smaller equipment packages, of $500,000 or less each, will be procured following international
shopping procedures. Civil works contracts estimated to cost more than $5 million will be carried
out using ICB procedures while those of $5 million equivalent or less will be carried out using
local  competitive  bidding  (LCB)  procedures  in  accordance  with  the  tendering  and  bidding  law
and  related  regulations.34  Local  contractors  have  the  necessary  expertise,  experience,  and
capacity  to  undertake  these  contracts.  However,  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines for
Procurement,  foreign  contractors  may  bid  on  contracts  using  LCB.  Civil  works  for  the  village
flood  protection  component  costing  $1  million  or  less  per  package  will  be  implemented  under
force account basis, since it would be difficult for local contractors to implement the component,
which  requires  close  coordination  with  large  numbers  of  villagers.  The  list  of  indicative
procurement packages is in Appendix 9.

b. 

Advance Action and Retroactive Financing

To start project implementation early, ADB approved advance procurement action,35 up
94.
to signing of the contracts. ADB also approved in principle retroactive financing in an amount of
about $2 million (i) as mobilization payment of $1.7 million for the civil work contractors for the
three  core  subprojects;  and  (ii)  $0.3  million  to  procure  vehicles  and  office  equipment  for  the
project office, from 9 July 2001 to date of effectiveness of the ADB loan. Retroactive financing is
required  because  the  construction  period  in  the  area  is  limited  by  cold  weather  in  winter  and
high  river water levels in  the summer and construction needs to start in September 2001. For
the  Kaifeng  core  subproject,  construction  noise  and  activities  must  be  substantially  reduced
from October to March to avoid disturbing the seasonal water fowl migration in the Liuyuankou
Nature Reserve. Hence, a deferment of civil works until the expected loan effectiveness in the
fourth  quarter  of  2001  would  entail  deferring  the  project  civil  works  by  another  year.  The
Government  requested  ADB  approval  for  advance  action  for  civil  works,  procurement  of
equipment and vehicles, and selection of consultant firms for the flood management component.
Advance recruitment of consultants will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging  domestic  consultants,
and advance procurement action will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement.
The Government has been advised that ADB's concurrence on advance action and retroactive
financing does not constitute ADB commitment to finance the relevant expenditures under the
Project or the Project itself.

97.

The imprest account will cover disbursement related to the Project, to a ceiling of 10 percent of

9. 

Report, Accounts, and Audit

98.
YRCC  will  prepare  quarterly  progress  reports  indicating  progress  made,  problems
encountered during the period under review, steps taken or proposed to remedy the problems,
the proposed program of activities, and the expected progress during the following quarter. For
the  village  flood  protection  component,  the  local  government  concerned  will  also  prepare
quarterly progress reports for subproject areas for which it is responsible. Both YRCC and the
local  governments  will  submit  their  respective  progress  reports  to  MWR.  Subsequently,  MWR
will  review  and  submit  the  progress  report  to  ADB.  In  addition  to  periodic  reporting  and
monitoring, ADB and the Government will jointly review project implementation at least once a
year to identify and resolve major issues.

99.
  Within  six  months  of  physical  completion  of  the  Project,  MWR  will  submit  to  ADB  a
completion report that describes subproject selection and design, implementation, actual costs
incurred in relation to cost estimates, benefits, beneficiary consultations, and other information
requested by ADB.

 25

100. MWR  will  maintain  separate  records  and  accounts  sufficient  to  identify  the  goods  and
services  financed  from  the  proceeds  of  the  loan,  the  financing  resources  received,  the
expenditures  incurred  for  the  Project,  and  the  use  of  local  funds.  The  accounts  will  be
established  and  maintained  in  accordance  with  sound  accounting  principles.  The  annual
consolidated project accounts and related financial statements for the Executing Agency will be
audited  and  translated  by  auditors  acceptable  to  ADB.36  The  audited  reports  and  related
financial  statements  will  be  submitted  to  ADB  not  later  than  nine  months  after  the  end  of  the
fiscal year to which they relate. The Government was informed of ADB’s policy on submission of
audited accounts, which covers failure in submitting audited accounts and financial statements
within the due date. A formal warning will be issued for accounts more than 6 months overdue
and disbursements will be suspended for accounts that are 12 months overdue.

10. 

Annual and Midterm Review

101.
The Government and ADB will review project implementation annually. In the third year,
they will carry out a midterm review of project achievements. The midterm review will critically
assess  the  project  parameters__including  both  physical  progress  as  well  as  progress  on  the
policy  agenda  and  institutional  performance__evaluate  whether  the  Project  will  achieve  the
intended  objectives  and  benefits,  and  take  appropriate  measures  including  modifying  design
and reallocating resources as necessary.

11. 

Project Monitoring and Evaluation

102. A set of indicators to estimate the project impact in relation to goals, purposes, outputs,
and conditions has been agreed upon by ADB and YRCC. The main items include (i) economic
development  and  poverty  indicators  in  the  project  area;  (ii)  hydrological  and  morphological
indicators such as frequency of flooding in the lower reaches of the Yellow River; (iii) physical
progress of the Project; and (iv) social impact indicators, including progress in relocation. YRCC
will prepare and maintain records of such information for at least five years after the completion
of civil works. YRCC will monitor and assess activities, and include the results in the quarterly
progress reports to ADB.

103. Project  monitoring  and  evaluation  (PME)  based  on  the  participatory  rural  appraisal
(PRA)  approach  will  be  undertaken  to  assess  changes  in  socio-economic  conditions  in  the
subproject area. The key PRA quantitative indicators are agricultural and commercial production
patterns;  incomes  and  expenditure  levels;  poverty  reduction  effects  though  income  and  social
capabilities;  access  to  public  and  private  technical,  social  services,  and  utilities;  and  village
organization.  An  international  specialist  and  domestic  consultants  will  work  together  to  advise
YRCC  on  appropriate  PRA  methods  and  give  field  training  in  applying  the  methods  during

G. 

Environmental and Social Measures

1. 

Environment

The  Project  is  in  environmental  category  B.  IEEs  were  prepared  for  the  three  core
108.
subprojects based on data collected during the feasibility studies, review of related reports, and
consultations  with  concerned  government  offices  and  affected  communities.  An  SIEE  was
circulated to the Board on 2 February 2001. The IEE concludes that the negative environmental
impacts  arising  from  construction  and  operation  of  project  facilities  can  be  kept  at  acceptable
levels through implementation of mitigation measures that will be monitored by an independent
institution  to  be  recruited  under  the  Project.  The  IEE  stated  that  EIA  was  not  required  for  the
three core subprojects. The IEE reports (translated into the local language) were made available
to  the public and other interested  parties in the Project’s field offices in Shandong and Henan
provinces.

109.
The  IEEs  for  the  candidate  subprojects  will  be  prepared  in  packages  considering  the
geographic  location,  similarity,  and  timing  of  subprojects  construction.  Approval  for  the
IEE/EIA38 of each package will be obtained from SEPA and ADB before construction starts. The
IEEs  will  be  prepared  in  accordance  with  relevant  Government  environmental  laws  and
regulations  and  ADB’s  environmental  guidelines.  During  implementation  and  operation  of  the
core  and  candidate  subprojects,  MWR/YRCC  will  also  comply  with  all  applicable  national,
provincial, and local environmental laws and regulations.

110.
The  Project  will  cause  some  negative  as  well  as  positive  environmental  impacts.
Potential negative environmental impacts include (i) temporary loss of farmland (151.3 ha) to be
used as borrow pits, temporary access roads, storage for pipelines, and construction sites; and
permanent  acquisition  of  land  (321.5  ha)  for  the  construction  of  warping39  areas,  tree  planting
for the wave protection belt, new village platforms, and road construction and widening; (ii) use
of  a  large  volume  of  groundwater  for  warping  of  earth  in  Kaifeng  and  Changyuan  and  its
disposal  after  use;  (iii)  temporary  large  contractors'  camps,  which  may  cause  social  tension
among villagers, water body contamination, and solid waste disposal; (iv) disturbance and illegal
hunting of migrating waterfowl and wildlife, particularly at the location close to the core area of
the  Liuyuankou  Wetland  Nature  Reserve;  (v)  potential  erosion  of  unconsolidated  material  in
areas  with  bare  soil  such  as  new  embankments,  newly  warped  areas,  temporary  roads,  and
construction  sites;  and  (vi)  use  of  heavy  machinery  and  a  large  number  of  construction-
associated  vehicles  that  may  cause  environmental  pollution  (emission,  used  oils,  grease,  tar,
and cement) and noise.

111.
The  mitigation  measures  are  as  follows:  (i)  affected  people  will  be  compensated,  and
income  opportunities  created  to  restore  the  livelihood  of  permanently  displaced  people;  (ii)
around  60  wells  will  be  uniformly  spread  in  each  of  the  subproject  areas  to  minimize  the
lowering  of  water  table,  and  excess  water  will  be  used  for  irrigation,  recycled  in  the  slurry
process  during  warping,  or  drained  into  the  Yellow  River;  (iii)  labor  camp  management  will

112.
The potential positive environmental impacts are as follows: (i) warping wastewater can
be used to irrigate farmland in the inner floodplain; (ii) the abandoned borrow pits will become
artificial  wetlands  of  value  to  wildlife  and  migrating  waterfowl;  and  (iii)  tree  planting  and
reforestation programs will produce better ground cover, reduce erosion, and generate income.

113. ESD40 in the PMO will monitor and supervise the implementation of mitigation measures
for the environmental and social impacts of the three core subprojects during the construction
and  operational  stages,  and  apply  this  experience  to  the  other  subprojects.  ESD  will  be
strengthened and will have an approved budget to support its staff. An international environment
specialist  will  be  recruited  to  assist  in  overall  environmental  management  of  the  core
subprojects,  including  incorporation  of  environmental  mitigation  measures  into  the  bidding
documents  and  contractor’s  contract,  and  advise  on  preparing  the  IEE/SIEE  of  the  candidate
subprojects  and  their  quality  assurance.  Overall,  ESD  will  give  advice  on  the  environmental
management of the core and candidate subprojects. In doing so, ESD staff will coordinate with
SEPA  and  the  environmental  protection  bureaus  in  the  provinces,  prefectures,  cities,  and
counties. Environmental monitoring during project construction and operation will (i) ensure that
construction is carried out according to design, and proposed mitigation measures are followed;
(ii)  identify  any  new  or  unforeseen  environmental  problems,  and  determine  how  they  can  be
addressed  and  mitigation  measures  formulated;  and  (iii)  ensure  that  environmental  and  social
impacts are minimized to acceptable levels.

114.
The key environmental issues in the basin are flooding and water shortages, erosion and
sedimentation,  surface  water  and  groundwater  pollution,  and  decline  in  biological  resources.
Structural  measures  to  manage  flooding  and  water  resources  should  be  complemented  with
long-term  measures.  Long-term  solutions  need  to  focus  on  increasing  rainfall  infiltration  and
water  retention,  and  achieving  acceptable  limited  flooding  in  the  lower  reaches.  In  practice,
these  entail  increasing  the  cover  of  perennial  vegetation,  especially  in  mountainous  areas,
limiting cultivation and expanding terracing in hilly areas, and establishing flood retention areas
in conjunction with land use planning.

2. 

Social Analysis

115. A range of data sources has been utilized and compared to derive statistical overviews
and  a  socioeconomic  profile  of  the  three  subproject  sites  in  the  context  of  a  river  basin  and  a
province.  National,  provincial,  and  county/city  yearbooks,  agency  annual  reports,  thematic
maps,  and  specialist  reports  provided  an  initial  overview.  These  were  supplemented  with
county-level  problem  identification  activities,  agency  and  local  leadership  interviews,  over  100
household  sample  surveys,  27  community  PRA  processes,  gender  analysis,  separate  group
interviews  with  men  and  women,  and  two  workshops  to  provide  feedback  and  receive
comments from key counterpart institutions. In all public consultations, there was strong support
for the Project.

116. Henan  and  Shandong  provinces  have  relatively  well-developed  provincial  and
agricultural economies. However, they have some poor areas that are particularly mountainous
and flood-prone. A significant portion of these areas is within the land protected by the Yellow
River  embankments.  Two  designated  provincial-level  poor  counties  are  in  the  proposed
subproject site at Dongping flood retention basin in Shandong. There is also a cluster of poverty
areas along sections of the Yellow River near subproject sites in neighboring Henan. Poverty in
these  areas  result  from  a  flood-prone  and  depleted  physical  environment,  loss  of  assets  and
income  as  a  result  of  floods,  and  unanticipated  effects  of  past  resettlement  at  some  sites.
Because of the perceived risks of floods, people are unwilling to restore or invest in community
infrastructure,  services  and  farm  production  assets  that  might  otherwise  attract  external
entrepreneurs,  or  support  self-funded  development.  Low  farm  product  prices  and  marketing
difficulties  present  additional  problems.  In  this  general  scenario,  household  poverty  is  further
exacerbated  by  illness;  high  household  dependency  ratios;  and  lack  of  labor,  job  skills,  and
qualifications.

117. Central, provincial, and local governments have responded to this through a number of
policy  measures,  including  development  of  interarea  linkages,  engineering  flood  protection
mechanisms, land improvement strategies and provision of poverty and relief support. However,
funding shortfalls, limited development of stable local income-earning opportunities, associated
technical support and credit availability continue to hamper rapid improvement.

H. 

Technical Assistance

118.
The current legal and institutional framework and arrangements do not allow for uniform
and effective management of the Yellow River basin. In line with the proposed amendment of
the  1988  Water  Law,  the  Government  will  enact  a  Yellow  River  Law  to  specifically  address
management  of  the  Yellow  River  water  resources  through  adoption  of  a  unified  administration
clearly defining the rights and responsibilities of each relevant department and local government
concerned. In this context, the Government requested ADB to provide a TA in conjunction with
the proposed loan to conduct a strategic planning study for preparing the Yellow River Law.

119.
The  TA  will  (i)  review  the  baseline  information  and  data  on  social,  environmental,
economic,  and  technical  conditions  of  the  Yellow  River  basin;  (ii)  identify  socioeconomic
development opportunities and assess the problems and constraints, giving due attention to the
specific  characteristics  of  the  river  and  the  diversified  nature  of  the  basin  area;  (iii)  review  the
relevant Government policies and plans as well as current institutional setup for water resources
management  in  general,  and  for  the  Yellow  River  in  particular;  (iv)  prepare  comprehensive
studies  pertaining  to  issues  in  effective  water  resources  management  and  sustainable

 30

socioeconomic  development  of  the  Yellow  River  basin;  and  (v)  prepare  policy  and  legal
recommendations for the formulation of the Yellow River Law.

120. About 80 person-months of consulting services will be needed: 17 international and 63
domestic. The TA cost is estimated at $1.27 million equivalent, comprising $562,000 in foreign

equivalent  on  a  grant  basis,  from  the  ADB-funded  TA  program,  to  cover  the  entire  foreign
exchange cost and part of the local currency cost, equivalent to $408,000. MWR will meet the
balance of the local currency cost, equivalent to $300,000 by providing office accommodations,
counterpart  staff,  field  surveys,  and  logistical  support.  The  consultants  will  be  selected  and
engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants,  and  other
arrangements  for  the  selection  and  engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  The  detailed  cost
