V. 

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Economic Evaluation

121. Economic  analyses  were  carried  out  for  the  three  core  subprojects  to  evaluate  the
returns on project investments to the economy (Appendix 12). The economic life of the project
structures is 40 years, including the construction period. A shadow exchange rate factor of 1.07
was  applied  to  derive  the  economic  cost  and  benefit  streams.  The  economic  wage  rate  of
unskilled labor is 90 percent of the financial wage rates. Estimated benefits from the subprojects
were  derived  based  on  avoidance  of  damage  to  existing  assets,  avoided  disruptions  to
agricultural and industrial production, and avoided emergency repairs of the flood embankment.
Key assets in the flood-prone areas include standing crops, public infrastructure, and buildings
(residential, commercial, and industrial). Potential disruption to economic activities is caused not
only  by  floodwater,  but  also  by  the  deposition  of  silt  on  agricultural  and  urban  areas,  which
would reduce agricultural outputs for at least one year and entail substantial recovery costs.

122.
To calculate the economic internal rates of return (EIRRs), core subproject benefits were
annualized by adjusting the total estimated flood damages by the probabilities of floods, under
the with-project and without-project scenarios. The magnitude of damage in different parts of the
flood-prone areas was adjusted according to the expected levels of inundation as simulated by
YRCC.  For  flood-prone  areas  with  lower  potential  economic  growth,  benefits  were  mostly
derived from the lower risk of damages. In areas with good potential for economic growth, such
as  Kaifeng  County,  benefits  were  largely  derived  from  enhanced  economic  growth  made
possible due to investment in the core subproject. Benefits from the platforms were calculated
as  those  of  the  embankments.  However,  potential  losses  due  to  flooding  were  limited  to  the
estimated loss of private and community properties on existing platforms because the platforms
do not protect assets outside the platforms.

123.
The  costs  of  subprojects  include  the  costs  of  land  acquired,  resettlement,  survey  and
designs,  construction,  construction  supervision,  environment  mitigation  measures,  and
subproject  management.  The  costs  of  land  acquisition  and  temporary  construction  sites  are
based  on  the  forgone  economic  agricultural  incomes,  estimated  at  about  Y8,925  per  ha  per
season. The estimated compensation costs for structures dismantled as part of the resettlement
activities were based on their reconstruction costs.

124.
The  estimated  EIRRs  are  14,  19,  and  17  percent  for  the  subprojects  at  Changyuan,
Kaifeng,  and  Dongping,  respectively.  Similar  EIRRs  are  expected  for  the  other  candidate

 31

subprojects to be included in the Project. These estimates are robust, given the relatively limited
scope of benefits accounted for in the economic evaluation. The benefit estimates excluded the
avoidance  of  injuries,  hospitalization,  loss  of  lives,  mobilization  of  flood-fighting  crews,  and
large-scale emergency evacuation that will occur during major floods. The economic evaluation
also excluded potential loss, such as loss due to disruption of communication and transportation
to  areas  adjacent  to  flood-prone  zones,  and  loss  of  household  assets,  livestock,  and  farm
machinery.  The  EIRRs,  therefore,  provide  conservative  estimates  of  the  true  social  and
economic benefits of the Project.

C. 

Impact on Poverty

126.
From  1994  to  2000,  the  PRC  implemented  a  poverty  reduction  program  in  counties
officially classified as poor by national or provincial standards in remote mountain, desert, and
loess  plateau  regions;  reservoir  catchments;  areas  with  endemic  local  disease;  and  former
revolutionary  bases.  Poor  transport,  environmental  instability,  slow  economic  growth,  lack  of
drinking water, and extremely harsh conditions for production and livelihood characterized those
locations.  A  national  workshop  in  1996  stressed  that  poverty  reduction  activities  should  reach
the  household  level,  respond  to  actual  situations  and  local  conditions,  respect  the  opinions  of
poor  households,  and  promote  self-motivation  and  participation.  A  national  poverty  policy,
confirmed  at  the  poverty  conference  jointly  convened  by  the  Government,  the  United  Nations
Development  Programme,  and  ADB  in  May  2000,  recognized  that  the  poor  are  now  found  in
both  designated  poor  and  non-poor  counties,  in  rural  and  urban  areas,  and  predominantly  in
western PRC. The poor and the near poor risk further impoverishment through environmental or
economic  shocks,  and  reducing  their  poverty  will  require  comprehensive  socioeconomic
approaches  and  participatory  methods.  Such  methods  and  approaches  need  to  be  gender
sensitive.  Predominantly  male  out-migration  to  undertake  seasonal  or  long-term  off-farm
employment has also resulted in women comprising a significant portion of the farm labor force
in  a  sector  characterized  by  relatively  low  returns,  particularly  for  undiversified  grain  crop
farming.

127. Based on Y1,000 per capita income poverty threshold,41 poverty incidence in the high-
risk  counties  is  estimated  at  11.8  percent  (13.2  percent  for  Henan  and  7.5  percent  for
Shandong). These are higher than the poverty incidence in Henan and Shandong as a whole,
which  stood  at  11.0  and  5.9  percent,  respectively,  in  1999.  The  number  of  poor  within  the  43

annum in 1999 prices (Source: The Leading Group for Poverty Reduction, the World Bank, and the United Nations
Development  Programme.  2000  China:  Overcoming  Rural  Poverty.  Paper  presented  at  the  International
Conference on China’s Poverty Reduction Strategy in Early 21st Century, Beijing, 16-18 May 2000).

 32

high-risk counties therefore, is about 3.9 million. Moreover, household surveys showed that 25.1
percent  of  the  population  or  8.2  million  persons  belonged  to  the  Y1,000-Y1,500/person-year
income bracket.  This group, as much as the poor, is particularly vulnerable to flood damages
and  consequent  losses  and  stresses.  These  income  levels  should  be  compared  with  the
Y2,000-Y2,500 loss per capita42 experienced in the past flooding in the areas. The data suggest
that  in  the  43  counties  alone,  a  major  flood  will  adversely  affect  about  12  million  persons  in
terms of incomes and standard of living.

The  average  per  capita  net  annual  incomes  in  the  core  subproject  areas  range  from
128.
Y1,386  to  Y2,202.  Poverty  incidence  at  the  subproject  sites  is  7.4-24  percent,  based  on  the
international  one-dollar-a-day  poverty  line.  In  areas  such  as  the  subproject  site  at  Dongping,
there are pockets of poverty where village-level per capita incomes fall below the poverty line.
Poverty in the floodplain is caused by location, lack of skills and income-earning opportunities
from  nonagriculture  livelihoods,  poor  health  status  of  adults  in  the  family,  and  frequent
household  relocations  due  to  floods  and  past  resettlement  policies.  Non-income  poverty
indicators  in  these  areas  include  seasonal  food  scarcity  in  some  counties  and  inadequate
access to clean water and sanitation. Adult illiteracy rates are 11-30 percent in nine villages in
Changyuan and Kaifeng, predominantly among women. In the case of Changyuan, most of the
poor reside on smaller and lower platforms with a greater risk of flooding. Their farms are small
and  agriculture,  particularly  grain  production,  provides  60-80  percent  of  household  income,
compared  with  40-45  percent  for  the  non-poor.  The  detailed  social  and  poverty  impact
assessment is in Appendix 13.

129. During implementation, the Project will generate incomes for the floodplain communities,
including  the  poor,  from  the  labor-intensive  construction  of  embankments  and  platforms.
Approximately 23.5 million person-days of manual employment will be generated, of which 2.4
million person-days will be needed at the three core subproject sites. This means employment
for  about  52,000  unskilled  laborers  over  the  next  four  years.  Based  on  the  estimated  poverty
incidence  at  the  subproject  sites  and  with  priority  to  the  poor  in  jobs  at  those  sites,  about  2.7
million  person-days  or  about  Y41  million  in  wages  will  be  directed  to  poor  households.  The
estimated  employment  created  excludes 
jobs  generated  by  construction  of  village
facilities__schools,  clinics,  and  utility  structures__on  the  new  platforms.  After  the  construction
period, jobs will also be available for maintaining the new village platforms. This is estimated at
14,600  person-days  per  year.  Although  project  activities  are  not  aimed  at  income  generation,
the  extra  incomes  earned  from  construction  work  will  give  households  the  rare  opportunity  to
build  savings  and,  thus,  accumulate  capital  for  income-generating  enterprises  and  reduce  the
risk of their falling back into poverty.

130.
In  relocating  houses  to  the  new  platforms,  which  is  voluntary,  the  Project  requires  that
part  of  or  the  full  relocation  costs  for  poor  households  be  met  by  the  national  and  local
governments. This particularly applies to the extremely poor whose poverty is long-term in nature
and relates to lack of employment, debilitating illnesses, or other incapacities. The group includes
those  who  are  old,  childless  and  infirm,  widowed,  or  orphaned.  The  extremely  poor  are  on  the
official register of the county civil affairs bureaus to receive state-provided clothing, medical care,
housing,  and  burial  expenses.  They  are  also  widely  recognized  by  other  villagers  as  a  discrete
group that can be publicly and fairly identified for access to preferential relocation assistance.

                                                
42 In 1999 prices, based on data from Changyuan and surrounding areas.

 D. 

Risks

33

131.
The project design takes into account potential technical and economic risks. The main
risks,  which  could  result  in  implementation  delays  and  cost  overruns,  are  associated  with
abnormal  rainfall  and  unexpected  floods  that  will  adversely  affect  the  construction  of
embankments  and  river  training  works  during  project  implementation.  To  mitigate  these  risks,
the  project  design  includes  measures  to  facilitate  rapid  implementation,  avoiding  construction
during  the  rainy  season.  Advance  action  for  procurement,  consultant  recruitment,  and
retroactive financing are expected to substantially shorten the time required to start construction
(para.  94).  Adequate  amounts  of  the  loan  proceeds  will  be  made  available  on  a  timely  basis
through imprest accounts (para. 97). The provision of project management consultants will also
expedite  subproject  selection  and  preparation  of  IEE/EIA  and  resettlement  plans.  These
measures should mitigate the risk of delayed implementation.

132. Although  the  ground  elevation  of  village  platforms  to  be  constructed  under  the  village
flood protection component will be designed for above normal floods, there is the risk of floods
exceeding  the  design  flood  level  (para.  68).  To  mitigate  the  risk,  the  Project  will  provide  an
effective flood forecasting and warning system, giving timely and accurate flood warnings to the
villagers who may need to evacuate the inner floodplain. The Project will provide the equipment
and software for the flood forecasting and warning system and the equipment of the emergency
rescue team.43

Appendix 3, page 1

DESCRIPTION OF CORE SUBPROJECTS

1.
Under the flood control works component, two core subprojects, Kaifeng embankments
reinforcement and Dongping flood retention, were studied; and under the village flood protection
component,  Changyuan  platform  was  studied.  The  following  paras.  briefly  describe  the  core
subprojects.

1. 

Kaifeng Embankment Reinforcement

2.
The project works entail strengthening over 8.4 kilometers (km) of the right embankment
of the Yellow River in the vicinity of Kaifeng City.  The works will improve embankment stability,
minimize  seepage  through  the  embankment  at  high  water  levels,  and  increase  the  time  an
erosive attack from the river would take to breach the embankment. High rates of seepage and
the consequent erosion of the embankment material pose the greatest threat of a breach.

3.
The  present  embankment  was  built  up  from  the  original  natural  levees  by  repeated
widening and raising through the years. The quality of construction works has varied according
to prevailing technical knowledge and sociopolitical conditions. Many structural problems have
accumulated  within  the  embankment  over  time:  (i)  non-homogeneous  soil,  (ii)  joints  between
construction layers, (iii) lack of proper compaction, (iv) historical breaches and avulsions leaving
weak foundations, (v) emergency repairs carried out with materials immediately available, and
(vi) wild animal dens and burrows.

4.
Construction  of  a  new  embankment  on  the  inner  floodplain  some  100  meters  (m)  from
the existing main embankment is proposed.  The area between the new and old embankments
will be filled with warped material.  Originally, warping was carried out using a sand-water mix
dredged  from  the  riverbed.    Recently,  it  was  found  that  more  suitable  warping  material  is
obtained from borrow pits on the floodplain close to the river. Where the new embankment and
warped area would affect existing settlements, a cutoff wall will be constructed in the old main
embankment, leaving the settlements undisturbed. The total length of the new embankment is
around 7 km, and the cutoff wall, 1.4 km.

The warping material is loosened and made into a slurry by high pressure hoses.  The
5.
slurry  is  pumped  overland  at  distances  up  to  5  km  to  the  area  between  the  embankments,
where it is discharged into prepared lined basins and allowed to drain and consolidate naturally.
By  greatly  increasing  the  width  of  the  embankment,  even  with  poor  construction  material,  the
stability  of  the  outer  slope  is  improved,  seepage  reduced,  and  the  distance  through  which  the
river would have to cut the embankment in the event of an erosive attack increased.

6.
Where  warping  would  entail  significant  relocation  of  villages  at  the  inner  foot  of  the
embankment,  cutoff  walls  are  proposed.  The  wall  is  constructed  along  the  center  line  of  the
embankment  from  the  relatively  impermeable  subsurface  to  the  embankment  crest,  creating  a
near  impermeable  barrier  within  the  embankment.    The  wall  may  be  a  cement-soil  mix  in  situ
piled wall, where the required depth is less than 16-18 m, or a diaphragm wall of nonreinforced
concrete  0.22  m  wide  for  greater  depths.  This  virtually  eliminates  seepage  and  the  threat  of
embankment failure from seepage erosion.  While the construction of the piled wall is relatively
straightforward, excavating the trench for the diaphragm wall will expose cracks and voids in the
embankment  structure.    Where  these  are  large,  techniques  to  construct  the  diaphragm  wall
have  to  be  perfected  by  the  Yellow  River  Conservancy  Commission  (YRCC),  which  will
continuously study the most efficient and economical way of preventing floods.

 43

Appendix 3, page 2

2. 

Dongping Flood Retention Basin

7.
The  subproject  is  in  Dongping,  Liangshan,  and  Wengshan  counties  of  Shandong
Province, and lies southeast of Dongping Lake. The Dongping flood retention basin consists of
a  209-square  kilometer  (km2)  natural  lake  (Dongping)  surrounded  by  an  embankment.
Immediately adjacent is an artificial 418 km2 second basin (outer lake) that is also surrounded
by an embankment.1 The Dongping flood retention basin is a vital link in flood management for
the lower reaches of the Yellow River and its main function is to cut off the Yellow River’s peak
floods,  and  maintain  the  discharge  in  Aishan  (just  downstream  of  Dongping's  outlet  to  the
Yellow River) at below 10,000 cubic meters per second (m³/s). This is achieved by diverting a
maximum  of  8,500  m³/s  into  the  flood  storage  area.  This  function  is  vital  for  safeguarding
strategic  locations  downstream,  such  as  Jinan  City  (capital  of  Shandong  Province),  railway
lines, and the oilfields. As the embankment has a number of structural weaknesses, significant
upgrading  is  necessary  to  make  it  safe.  The  subproject  focuses  on  upgrading  the  outer
embankment  along  the  artificial  outer  lake  and  removing  unused  old  irrigation  facilities.  The
subproject’s  main  components  consist  of  (i)  constructing  about  18  km  of  diaphragm  walls;  (ii)
reconstructing  stone  armoring  of  embankment  along  about  22  km,  and  placing  geotextile
material  to  strengthen  the  embankment  and  allow  plants  to  grow;  (iii)  dismantling  two  disused
sluices;  and  (iv)  upgrading  10  sections  of  auxiliary  roads  along  a  total  length  of  about  900  m,
and constructing 19 flood observation houses with platforms.

8.
Owing  to  wind-generated  waves  in  the  basin,  stone  armoring  is  required  up  to  the
predicted wave height when the basin is filled.  Along the entire length, the armoring has to be
raised by 1.0-1.5 m in places. The existing stone armoring is in a state of partial collapse and
has  to  be  rebuilt  on  a  proper  base.    Along  the  embankment  are  two  irrigation  sluice  gates
designed to release water to the outer area for irrigation.  The gates date from the original multi-
purpose  reservoir  design  and  are  no  longer  in  use.    The  sluices  lie  on  old  river  courses  and
represent weak points in the embankment. They will be removed and the embankment rebuilt.

3. 

Changyuan Platforms

9.
To increase the security of the villagers living in the inner floodplain (i.e., unprotected by
embankments),  it  is  proposed  that  raised  platforms  be  built  for  five  villages  with  a  total
population  of  4,619,  together  with  improvements  on  the  evacuation  roads  and  bridges.    The
villages are around 4 km from the main embankment, and 2 km from the main river course.

Based on a per capita area of 60 square meters (m2), the total plan area of the platforms
10.
in all five villages will be 650,000 m2.  Accommodation for the villagers will be constructed on the
platforms, 17 m2 per capita totaling 78,500 m2.  A new platform with one-storey houses is the
preferred  option.2    It  offers  a  "cleaner"  engineering  solution  and  also  simplifies  resettlement
planning.

11.
A road will be constructed to the top of the platform, and the main roads in the villages
will  be  paved  (total  of  11.2  km),  new  school  buildings  in  the  villages  constructed  (5,000  m2),
drainage channels provided, and a belt of trees planted around the villages. Narrow earth tracks
serving two villages will be paved over a distance of 12 km and two minor bridges rebuilt.  The

                                                
1 Currently, the lake bottom area is fully cultivated by farmers living outside of the retention basin. The area is strictly

controlled by the local governments to prevent the migration of people from outside.

2 A comparative study of one-storey houses with higher platforms and two-storey houses with lower platforms was

made.

 44

Appendix 3, page 3

150-m  bridge  across  the  Wenyan  Channel  will  be  rebuilt  at  a  higher  level  and  widened  to  a
double carriageway.

12.
The  borrow  pit  for  the  material  to  raise  the  platforms  will  be  located  around  1  km  from
the  main  river  beyond  a  low  embankment  constructed  by  local  people.    The  land,  though
cultivated in the dry season, is reportedly flooded most years.  It is proposed to make a slurry of
the material in the borrow pit and pump the slurry to temporary spoil tips adjacent to the villages,
a technique known as warping, over a distance of 1 to 2 km.

SECTOR LENDING ARRANGEMENTS FOR LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT

A.

Introduction

In  accordance  with  ADB’s 

involuntary  resettlement  policy,  resettlement  will  be
1.
implemented  through  the  resettlement  policy  framework  (RPF)  and  resettlement  procedural
guidelines  (RPG).  RPF  and  RPG  stipulations  apply  to  all  subprojects  that  are  prepared  and
approved for inclusion in the sector loan. Three core subproject resettlement plans (RPs) have
already  been  prepared  for  the  Kaifeng,  Changyuan,  and  Dongping  subprojects  in  accordance
with the RPF and RPG and these will form models for land acquisition and resettlement under
new subprojects.

B.

Resettlement Policy Framework

2.
The  RPF  reflects  both  borrower’s  regulations  and  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary
resettlement.  The  main  RPF  principles  follow:  (i)  minimize  negative  impacts  as  much  as
possible, (ii) carry out resettlement and compensation so as to improve or at least restore the
pre-project living standards of the affected people (AP), (iii) fully inform and consult closely with
APs on compensation options and RP design, (iv) provide asset compensation at replacement
rates,  and  (v)  provide  compensation  for  lost  assets  and  resettlement  subsidies  in  full  prior  to
ground  leveling  and  demolition.  Disbursement  for  each  subproject  will  be  conditional  upon
ADB’s approval of the subproject RP.

3.
The  RPF  stipulates  eligibility  and  entitlement  provisions  for  land  losses,  house  losses,
crop losses, and loss of other assets. Land losses will be compensated as follows: (i) APs losing
agricultural  and  residential  land  will  be  compensated  through  land-for-land  arrangements,  or
land  reallocation  within  village  domains;  (ii)  if  land-for-land  arrangements  are  not  feasible,  the
AP  losing  agricultural  land  will  be  reclassified  and  provided  with  job  opportunities;  (iii)  cash
compensation  for  lost  land  will  be  paid  at  the  rates  stipulated  by  the  1998  Land  Law  to  the
villages  which,  in  turn,  will  use  the  funds  received  for  infrastructure  and  services  directly
benefiting  the  affected  communities.  Resettlement  subsidies  for  land  acquired  will  be  directly
paid to the AP in cash through the village offices. Compensation for house losses will be paid
directly to the AP in cash at replacement cost free of demolition costs and salvaged materials.
Compensation  for  crop  losses will  be  paid  directly  to  the  AP  in  cash  at  current  market  prices.
Vulnerable  households  will  receive  assistance  for  house  relocation  and  reconstruction,  to  be
organized  by  the  Village  Committee.    The  Environmental  and  Social  Division  (ESD)  in  the
Yellow  River  Conservancy  Commission  (YRCC)  will  pay  particular  attention  to  developing
effective income restoration strategies for APs below the poverty line.

C.

Resettlement Procedural Guidelines

4.
Appropriate RPs have been prepared for the three core subprojects. For subprojects yet
to be identified, specific RPGs have been established to guide RP preparation and to provide a
differentiated approach commensurate with the magnitude of the impact of each subproject.

5.
The established RPGs require the following procedures: (i) after subproject identification
and completion of preliminary technical design, YRCC carries out an impact survey to determine
the  magnitude  of  impacts;  (ii)  if,  through  this  process,  the  subproject  impacts  are  identified  as

 52

Appendix 7, page 2

significant,1  YRCC  will  prepare  a  full RP; (iii)  if  the  initial  screening  concludes  that  subproject
impacts are less than significant, YRCC will instead prepare a short RP. 2

D. 

 Institutional Responsibilities

6.
The  Ministry  of  Water  Resources  (MWR)  through  YRCC  has  overall  coordination,
planning,  implementation  and  financing  responsibilities.  Local  city  or  county  governments,
through  the  resettlement  offices,  will  be  responsible  for  implementing  the  agreed-upon  RPs,
including assets valuation, consultation, and delivery of entitlements. The local city and county
land  management  bureaus  are  responsible  for  land  recording  and  acquisition  approvals.  Field
tasks such as paying entitlements, selecting replacement land, providing livelihood support, and
monitoring will be the responsibility of township officers.

7.
MWR through YRCC will ensure that the resettlement offices are briefed on these RPF
and  RPG  arrangements  for  subproject  developments,  and  on  RPs  once  they  are  prepared.
MWR  through  YRCC  will  ensure  that  resettlement  budgets  are  delivered  on  time  to  the
provinces,  that  payments  are  made  directly  and  on  time  to  the  villages  and  the  individuals
affected, and that any shortfalls required to meet resettlement objectives are made good. The
entitlements will be given to the affected people before ground leveling and demolition start, or
else income support will be provided for the period of dislocation.

E.

Disclosure, Consultation, and Grievance Redress

8.
Each  RP  will  be  prepared  and  implemented  in  close  consultation  with  APs  and  will
involve  surveys  and  village  meetings.  RPs  in  the  Chinese  language  will  be  made  available  to
the public in township offices. Complaints and grievance procedures will be established in each
RP. Grievances will first be lodged with the village committee. If no settlement is reached within
two  weeks,  the  complainant  has  one  month  to  elevate  the  grievances  to  the  County  Land
Management  Bureau.  If  still  unresolved  within  two  weeks,  the  case  can  be  sent  to  the
correspondence  departments  of  other  government  agencies  or  the  resettlement  office.  Final
appeal  is  available  in  the  civil  courts  as  established  by  the  Regulations  for  Administrative
Redress.

F.

Monitoring and Evaluation

9.
YRCC will establish a monthly reporting system involving resettlement staff at township
and county level. External monitoring will be assigned to an independent agency. MWR/YRCC
will report to ADB on land acquisition and resettlement in the quarterly progress report.

G. 

Resettlement Cost

10.
The cost of resettlement and land acquisition for the three core subprojects is estimated
at  $7.21  million.  The  amount  comprises  asset  compensation,  including  land  and  resettlement;
income restoration assistance; management costs; monitoring and evaluation; and taxes. Cost
estimates will be adjusted annually based on the inflation rate in the previous year.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR
STRATEGIC PLANNING STUDY FOR THE PREPARATION
OF THE YELLOW RIVER LAW

The objectives of the technical assistance (TA) are to conduct strategic studies relating

1.
to integrated water resources management of the Yellow River basin and to search for legal
countermeasures for outstanding problems in the Yellow River basin, to provide the National
People’s Congress (NPC) with data and recommendations in formulating the Yellow River Law.

A. 

Objectives

B. 

Scope

2.
The TA will (i) review the baseline information and data on social, environmental,
economic, and technical conditions of the Yellow River basin; (ii) identify socioeconomic
development opportunities and assess problems and constraints, giving due attention to the
specific characteristics of the river and the diversified nature of the basin area; (iii) review
relevant Government policies and plans as well as the current institutional setup for water
resources management in general, and for the Yellow River in particular; (iv) prepare
comprehensive studies of the issues for effective water resources management and sustainable
socioeconomic development of the Yellow River basin; and (v) propose policy and legal
recommendations in formulating the Yellow River Law.

The study will cover seven themes: (i) water resources management: focusing on a
3.
comprehensive management system and mechanism for allocating and saving water, identifying
the supply and demand relationships between sustainable use of water resources and
socioeconomic development; (ii) water resources protection: focusing on the study of the
responsibilities and regulations for protecting water resources and preventing pollution; (iii) flood
protection and river management: river dredging and river training, including structural and
nonstructural measures, and establishing effective flood control and disaster mitigation
mechanisms, risk management system, and policy; (iv) soil and water conservation: setting
rules and regulations for integrated planning and management emphasizing comprehensive
benefit evaluation through participatory approaches; (v) water pricing and cost recovery
mechanism: evaluating and exploring the most efficient and effective mechanisms for collecting
fees or levying charges or taxes on water users or beneficiaries, giving due consideration to
affordability to the poor; (vi) financing mechanisms: assessing the financial capabilities of each
level of the governments (central, provincial and cities/counties) for investment in basin
management and studying responsibilities in basin management of all levels of government and
basin administrative agencies; and (vii) management and institution: assessing international
best practices and exploring the possibilities for the most effective and efficient unified basin
management system and administration in the Yellow River basin.

C. 

Cost Estimates and Financing Plan

The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,270,000 equivalent, comprising $562,000 in

4.
foreign exchange and $708,000 equivalent in local currency. The Asian Development Bank
(ADB) will provide a grant of $970,000 from the ADB-funded TA program to cover the entire
foreign exchange cost and $408,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The Government will
contribute the balance of the local currency cost of $300,000 equivalent (Table A11).

 58

Appendix 11, page 2

D. 

Implementation Arrangements

Ministry of Water Resources (MWR) will be the Executing Agency and Yellow River

5.
Conservancy Commission (YRCC) the implementing agency. An international consultant firm
will be primarily responsible for undertaking studies and developing practical recommendations
for the promulgation of the forthcoming Yellow River Law. Given the strategic importance and
the involvement of various sectors, a national steering committee (NSC) will be established for
coordinating the activities of the relevant ministries, agencies of local governments as well as for
supervising the TA. The members of NSC will be relevant specialists and representatives from
the State Development Planning Commission, Ministry of Finance, MWR, Ministry of
Agriculture, Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Development, State Environment
Protection Administration, State Forestry Administration, and other government agencies as well
as representatives of the relevant local governments. Under supervision and coordination by
NSC, the project management office (PMO) of YRCC will work closely with the consultants to be
engaged under the TA.

The TA will be completed in nine months beginning in November 2001, by a team of

6.
international consultants in association with domestic consultants (80 person-months in total).
The international consultants (17 person-months) will be engaged through a firm and selected in
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The consultants (person-months
and category in parentheses) will have expertise in (i) water resources management (7
international, 9 domestic); (ii) environmental policy analysis and planning and water pollution (2
international, 9 domestic); (iii) institutional strengthening, with knowledge of and experience in
tax, charges, fees, and pricing issues (3 international, 9 domestic); (iv) legal issues with
knowledge of river basin management (3 international, 9 domestic); (v) macroeconomic
planning, with experience in regional development (2 international, 9 domestic); (vi) socio-
anthropology, with experience in poverty reduction and ethnic minority issues (9 domestic); and
(vii) flood management (9 domestic). A domestic consultant with knowledge of soil conservation
will be engaged for four months. Consultants will procure equipment1 in accordance with ADB’s
Guidelines for Procurement.

The PMO of YRCC will work closely with the consultants as counterpart staff. Additional
7.
counterpart staff will be provided as and when necessary. The involvement of stakeholders will
be sought throughout the TA. The first NSC meeting, workshop, and tripartite meeting will be
held at an early stage of TA implementation to promote participation at all levels, agree on the
approach to implementing the TA, and determine the detailed scope of the TA. Workshop
participants will include representatives from the relevant ministries and provincial governments
as well as relevant specialists. Representatives from external funding agencies, the private
sector, and civil society will be also invited, but the TA will not fund their attendance, except for
the persons invited to serve as resource speakers. Representatives from the World Bank and
Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID) will be invited to present their
preliminary findings and lessons obtained from the ongoing Yangtze River Flood Control and
Management Project. The second NSC meeting, workshop, and tripartite meeting will be
organized at the TA’s midterm to present preliminary findings and to elicit feedback. The two
NSC meetings and workshops will coincide with tripartite meetings. At each workshop, the
consultants will provide concise reports for discussions. The reports will be revised and
submitted to the Government and ADB for approval at the conclusion of each tripartite meeting.

It will be useful to have overseas consultation to observe the comprehensive large-scale

8.
and advanced river basin management systems in ADB’s member countries and to exchange
views on river basin management with officials. The cost for overseas consultation will not
exceed 4 percent of the total TA budget.

A final report incorporating comments from the Government, ADB, and workshop
9.
participants, including key Government policy makers and experts from academic societies, the
private sector, civil society, and other relevant specialists, will be submitted within one month of
the conference. The final report will be published in both Chinese and English. The TA is
expected to be completed in August 2002.

Appendix 12, page 1

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL EVALUATION

A. 

Introduction

The economic costs and benefits of the core subprojects were assessed to evaluate the
1.
economic returns on the investments made in the subprojects. The analysis was conducted for
an asset life span of 40 years, including the construction period. This estimate is conservative
for the types of structures built. The costs and benefits were expressed in constant 2000 prices,
and valued using the domestic price numeraire method. All taxes and duties were excluded in
deriving the economic values. Furthermore, the financial costs of traded goods were adjusted to
their respective economic values using a shadow exchange rate factor (SERF) of 1.07,1 and the
shadow wage rate for unskilled labor was estimated at 0.9 of the prevailing wage rate. All other
local  currency  costs  were  assumed  to  equal  their  economic  costs,  after  taxes  and  duties  are
deducted.

2.
Since  the  Yellow  River  Conservancy  Commission  (YRCC)  does  not  generate  revenue
from its flood protection services, and it is not operated as a financially independent entity, the
financial  internal  rates  of  return  of  the  subproject  investments  to  YRCC  are  not  a  relevant
indicator  of  subproject  sustainability  and  therefore  were  not  calculated.  Financial  evaluation
focused instead on the capacity of YRCC to sustain operation and maintenance (O&M) of the
facilities built under the Project.

B. 

Economic Costs

The  subproject  costs  include  the  costs  of  land  acquired,  voluntary  and  involuntary
3.
resettlement, surveys and design, construction, construction supervision, environment mitigation
measures, and subproject management. The costs of land permanently acquired or temporarily
disturbed were based on the average value of crop harvests, averaged at Y8,925 per hectare
per year. The costs of buildings to be dismantled due to subproject construction were based on
their  replacement  or  reconstruction  costs.  The  economic  costs  and  benefits  of  the  capacity-
building activities for YRCC and its regional offices were not analyzed since the economic value
of institutional strengthening cannot be reliably estimated. Since the subprojects will rehabilitate
and  strengthen  existing  structures,  there  is  potential  for  savings  on  O&M  costs  in  the  future.
However, due to lack of firm data, the potential savings were also not analyzed.

C.

Economic Benefits

4.
Benefits  were  based  on  flood  damage  avoidance  due  to  the  subproject  investments.
Potential  damage  includes  losses  in  fixed  assets  (crops,  agriculture  land,  homes,  public
infrastructure, and industrial equipment and facilities); temporary disruptions of agricultural and
industrial  production;  costs  of  emergency  evacuation;  repair  of  flood  control  structures;  and
stunted  investment  and  economic  growth  due  to  the  prevailing  flood  risk.  Only  direct  and
quantifiable benefits attributable to flood protection were included in the benefit estimation.

For  the  Changyuan  platforms,  the  potential  flood  damages  were  calculated  from  the
5.
estimated  value  of  assets  on  the  existing  platforms,  derived  from  field  surveys  conducted  in
2000. The damage estimates were limited to assets on top of the platforms since the subproject
interventions will not protect assets outside the platforms. The extent (percent) of asset losses
varies with the level of inundation, types of asset affected, and size of inundated area. These, in

                                                          
1  SERF is the inverse of the standard conversion factor (SCF), which is 0.93.

 61

turn,  are  linked  to  the  probabilities  of  river  flow  rate  and  height  of  the  platforms.  The  new
platforms are designed to provide effective protection against normal floods.

6.
Using historical inundation data and asset loss rates on the existing platform and a flood
damage  simulation  model  on  the  new  platforms,2  total  economic  losses  were  estimated  for
varying  levels  of  flood  severity,  for  the  with-  and  without-Project  scenarios  (Table  A12.1).
Average annual damages for Changyuan were, in turn, computed by estimating the area under
the  damage-frequency  curve  (flood  frequency  plotted  against  associated  damages).  Table  1
presents  the  annual  damages  for  the  with-  and  without-project  scenarios  and  the  incremental
annual damage avoidance, estimated at Y7.6 million.

E.

Operation and Maintenance Requirements

11.
Operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  of  the  embankment,  warping  and  cutoff  walls,  and
other related infrastructure range from Y60,000 to Y80,000 per kilometer per year, inclusive of
Y20,000 in staff and overhead costs. The costs generally correlate to the dimension (width and
height) of embankments in a particular location. The costs exclude in-kind material contributions
from communities. In the past five years (1996-2000), YRCC has received adequate budgetary
support  from  the  central  Government  to  meet  the  O&M  requirements  amounting  to  about  Y98
million  per  year  for  the  lower  reach  of  the  Yellow  River.  These  were  allocated  to  O&M,  and
repair and rehabilitation budget line items of YRCC.

12.
The  repairs  and  strengthening  of  aging  river  infrastructures  under  the  Project  are
expected  to  somewhat  lower  the  O&M  cost  of  these  structures,  at  least  in  the  medium  term.
Nonetheless, YRCC does not foresee significant reduction in O&M commitment after the Project
and expects that adequate maintenance will be available for structures built under the Project.
Since  flood  protection  remains  a  priority  intervention  area  for  the  local  and  national
governments, YRCC expects to receive O&M budget allocations that are at least equal, in real
terms, to the resources provided in 1996-2000. Through the asset management improvements
to be carried out under the Project, YRCC expects to obtain more up-to-date and precise data
on infrastructure conditions. This will enable the agency to better estimate and allocate the O&M
budget requirements in the future.

 64

Appendix 13, page 1

SOCIAL AND POVERTY IMPACT ASSESSMENT

A. 

Government Policies on Poverty Reduction

The  People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  National  Poverty  Reduction  Plan  (1994-2000)
1.
designated both the loess plateau and reservoir catchment areas as two of the five typical areas
where  poverty  is  concentrated.  The  two  locations  are  characterized  by  poor  transport
infrastructure,  environmental  degradation,  slow  economic  growth,  and  low  suitability  for
agriculture  and  livelihood.  National  and  provincial  governments  further  designated  official  poor
counties  as  the  target  for  poverty  reduction  activities.  In  1996,  the  Government  stressed  that
poverty  reduction  efforts  should  reach  the  household  level  and  adapt  to  local  circumstances,
respect  the  aspirations  of  the  poor,  and  promote  self-help.  Recent  policies  recognize  that  the
poor are found in both designated poor and non-poor counties, in rural and urban areas but with
higher  concentrations  in  the  western  provinces.  Because  the  assisted  poor  easily  revert  to
poverty  because  of  adverse  environment  or  economic  shocks,  reducing  their  poverty  requires
comprehensive socioeconomic interventions and participatory methods.

2.
For the central and eastern provinces (including the flood-prone area to benefit from the
Project),  poverty  reduction  efforts  will  involve  (i)  identifying  locally  appropriate  mechanisms  to
address  the  remaining  clusters  of  poverty,  (ii)  mobilizing  national  support  and  human  and
financial  resources  in  the  relatively  well-off  areas  to  assist  poverty  reduction  efforts,  and    (iii)
strengthening  water  management  infrastructure  along  the  lower  reaches  of  the  major  rivers  to
prevent  severe  floods  that  contribute  to  major  relapses  into  poverty.    National,  provincial,  and
local  governments  have  been  addressing  poverty  and  regional  disparity  through  a  number  of
measures,  including  development  of  transport  infrastructure,  prevention  of  floods  and
management  of  natural  calamities,  land  improvements,  and  direct  relief  assistance.  However,
budget  constraints,  limited  development  of  income-generating  opportunities,  and  lack  of
technical  extension  assistance  and  credit  availability  continue  to  hamper  poverty  reduction
efforts.

B. 

Socioeconomic Characteristics of the Yellow River Basin

The  Yellow  River  crosses  nine  provinces  in  its  5,464-kilometer  journey  from  western
3.
PRC to the Bohai Sea. The total catchment area occupies 795,000 square kilometers (km2) and
contains  about  18  percent  of  the  nation’s  farmland.    However,  available  arable  land  has  been
decreasing  sharply  due  to  severe  erosion,  particularly  in  the  relatively  poor  Loess  Plateau
region  of  the  upper  and  middle  reaches.  This,  in  turn,  contributes  to  high  rates  of  river
sedimentation, which can exacerbate flooding in the lower reach. High rates of water extraction
in the upper reaches also produce water shortages downstream in the drier months and have
encouraged the widespread practice of storing water among households and industries. Heavy
water extraction also reduces awareness of flooding as a potential danger among populations
outside  the  embankments.  This  is  particularly  the  case  where  many  locations  have  not
experienced significant flooding in the last 50 years.

C. 

Characteristics of the Project Area

4.
Although  the  boundaries  of  the  lower  river  catchment  area  are  well-defined,  the
demarcation of flood-prone area to benefit from the Project (i.e., project area) follows the county
administrative  lines  and  therefore  is  less  precise.  The  project  feasibility  study  identified  113

 65

Appendix 13, page 2

counties within flood-prone areas in the river’s lower reach (i.e., project area),1  while  a  Yellow
River  Conservancy  Commission  study  in  1996  showed  that  43  of  the  113  counties  are
particularly  vulnerable  to  inundation  since  they  are  located  along  the  Yellow  River  and  its
tributaries. The 113 counties are in the provinces of Henan, Shandong, Anhui, and Jiangsu, with
the  43  counties  at  highest  risk  confined  to  Henan  and  Shandong.  The  project  area  covers
117,900 km2 and has an estimated population of 85 million. Hence, it is densely populated with
723 persons/km2. Table A13.1 presents the characteristics of the flood-prone counties, grouped
according to their vulnerability to floods.

5.
Across  60  percent  of  the  project  area  is  relatively  flat  topography  that  facilitated  the
development  of  11  major  cities,  dense  transportation  networks,  key  national  north-south  road
and rail interchanges, and generally easy market access for industrial and agricultural products.
Parts  of  the  area  are  also  of  historical  significance.  An  area  of  49,600  km2  that  covers  the  43
counties  in  Henan  and  Shandong  and  is  particularly  prone  to  inundation  has  a  population  of
32.8  million,  including  28.8  million  in  agriculture  whose  livelihood  and  crops  are  particularly
vulnerable  to  floods.  These  counties  are  likely  to  suffer  the  most  and  intermediate  potential
damages in the event of a flood (columns 1 and 2 in Table A13.1). The project area includes the
inner  floodplains  (i.e.,  areas  inside  the  main  river  embankments).  The  inner  plains,  which
coincide with 85 percent of the lower river catchment area (4,647 km2), are home to 1.7 million
residents  living  in  2,193  villages.  The  inner  plains  are  relatively  densely  populated  (431
persons/km2) and highly vulnerable to floods.

Compared with the provinces in the western region, Shandong and Henan are relatively

7.
Surveys  in  the  core  subproject  areas  suggest  that  the  incidence  of  poverty  at  Kaifeng,
Changyuan,  and  Dongping  are  12,  24  and  7.4  percent,  respectively.3  Relative  poverty  and
deprivation in the flood-prone areas are caused by many factors: natural calamities, which are
mainly  flooding,  depleted  natural  resources,  lack  of  access  to  markets,  and  low  farm  output
prices.  Individual  hardship  is  exacerbated  by  illness,  high  household  dependency  ratios,  and
lack of labor and skills. In the inner floodplains, houses are usually single-storey, farm sizes are
small averaging 0.4 ha, no additional land can legally be brought into production, drinking water
is  sourced  from  wells,  and  savings  are  sunk  in  livestock  and  assets  that  are  prone  to  flood
damage.  Interviews  with  residents  indicate  that  the  psychological  impact  of  losing  homes,
possessions,  and  confidence  in  future  security  is  significant.  Most  of  the  poor  reside  on  lower
flood  platforms  with  greater  risk  of  flooding.  In  the  subproject  areas,  agriculture,  particularly
cultivation of grains, provides 80 percent of income for the poor, whereas non-poor households
derive  45  percent  of  their  incomes  from  off-farm  employment.  Dependence  on  relatives  and
local  agencies  increases  in  times  of  natural  calamities,  since  rural  financial  markets  are
relatively  weak  and  insurance  schemes  are  practically  nonexistent.  The  income-generation
capacity  of  poorer  residents  in  the  core  subproject  areas  is  hampered  by  higher  rates  of
illiteracy  and  lower  levels  of  education,4  lack  of  sufficient  or  surplus  labor,  lack  of  access  to

8.
Substantial progress has been achieved in reducing poverty in the project provinces. In
Henan,  official  figures  indicate  that  the  proportion  of  the  poor  (measured  by  the  provincial
poverty  line)  in  the  total  rural  population  declined  from  38  percent  to  4  percent  between  1979
and 1988—net reduction of 21.8 million persons classified as poor. Almost 92 percent of rural
houses  in  the  province  are  now  constructed  from  brick  and  wood  or  reinforced  concrete,  and
house  space  per  capita  reached  23  square  meters.  Average  provincial  figures  for  net  farmer
income per capita also indicate improved standards of living. Statistics from neighboring flood-
prone  Shandong  Province  also  show  a  decline  in  the  number  of  the  poor  from  7.6  million  in
1984 to 4 million in 1993.

Although creating the necessary environment for income generation, the Project will not

(ii) 

Priority in employment will be given to poor households, particularly in
constructing and maintaining the platforms and other related local facilities.

E. 

Project Employment Impact

12.
The  civil  works  under  the  Project  are  expected  to  generate  significant  employment
opportunities and incomes to the communities, including the poor. For the Project as a whole,
approximately  23.5  million  person-days  of  unskilled  labor  will  be  required,  of  which  2.4  million
person-days will be needed for the construction of the core subprojects (Table A13.3). With an
average  employment  span  of  3  months/person  per  year,  the  Project  is  expected  to  employ
about  52,000  unskilled  laborers  over  the  next  four  years.  Based  on  the  estimated  poverty
incidence  at  the  subproject  sites  and  with  priority  to  the  poor  in  obtaining  employment  at  the
construction sites, it is estimated that 2.7 million person-days or about Y41 million in wages will
be directed to poor households.

No  additional  employment  opportunity  will  be  created  for  embankment  maintenance
13.
since operation and maintenance efforts and resources devoted to the river embankments will
be roughly the same with or without the Project. Incremental employment opportunity, however,
will  be  generated  from  the  maintenance  of  new  village  platforms.  This  is  conservatively
estimated  at  14,600  person-days  per  year.  Employment  under  the  Project  will  not  be  a
sustainable  income-generating  activity  in  itself,  but  the  additional  incomes  earned  will  enable
households to build savings and accumulate capital to undertake income-generating ventures.

F. 

Distribution of Project Benefits

14.
The  three  core  subprojects  were  analyzed  to  assess  the  distribution  of  subproject
benefits  to  project  stakeholders:  the  households,  industry  (including  state-owned  enterprises),
and the public sector/economy. An assessment was also undertaken to determine the extent to
which  the  Project  directly  benefits  the  poor.  The  economic  analysis  showed  benefits  to
households were derived from employment opportunities, and direct avoidance of flood damage
to crops and houses and disruption in farming activities. Industries will benefit from the Project
in  the  form  of  reduced  risk  to  flood  damage  and  interruption  in  operations,  while  the  public
sector  will  benefit  from  damage  avoidance  on  public  infrastructure  and  savings  of  flood
evacuation costs of the affected population. During the construction period, laborers will accrue
benefits from employment opportunities at the sites. The public sector will gain tax incomes, but
will have to bear most of the costs of investment. Tables A13.4-13.6 present the results of the
distribution analyses. The poverty impact ratios are 0.93 for Changyuan, 0.17 for Kaifeng, and
0.06 for the Dongping subproject.
